The entrepreneurship bank, El Colegio Sur,  is comprised of ten members (nine women and one man) all of whom engage in different activities such as car upholstery, and sales of fruit shakes, cell phone covers, juices, perfumes, soft drinks, and clothing. In order to apply for a loan and expand their businesses, this bank has had credit with the institution previously. Due to problems within the group they have restructured about 30% with people who know each other.

Elena is the group's representative (in the photo she is the one seated in the middle). She is 45 years old and has two children, 24 and 16 years old. She sells clothing.  She is a good mother and an independent, enterprising, hard-working, and responsible person. She sells in the southern region, where trade and commerce are increasing. It has a tropical climate and is humid with constant temperatures of 30 degrees Centigrade (86 F) all year.

Elena has a dark complexion, is of medium height and stocky build, and has long, black, curly hair. Her mother tongue is Qechua and she speaks Spanish. She lives a private house belonging to her family.  It is built of bricks and has potable water and electricity. 

Her desire to get ahead motivated her to form a bank with people who have a variety of businesses. She sells seasonal items. For example: at Christmastime she buys toys, decorations, Christmas trees, lights, etc. at wholesale and sells them at fairs and markets. When this season is over, she buys things for Carnival such as costumes, water balloons, water guns, and clothing (which she sells at both times of year). Her marketing varies by the date and holiday.

Her dream is to have her own store in a fixed place of business so she doesn't have to be a street vendor. At this time she wants to buy her merchandise (clothing) at wholesale so she can sell it before the end-of-year holidays and keep her business running.

This is the second loan sequence with the institution in the ten years she has been in business. This is why Elena is asking for a loan: to buy seasonal clothing at wholesale so she can sell it for the end-of--year holidays.

loans.use: to buy seasonal clothing at wholesale.

loans.name: Hesti

texts.en:
Hesti is a 43-year-old woman who is married to Maxi, a 48-year-old man. From their marriage, they are blessed with five children. Ebenhezer, 21, and Monalisa, 19, are university students; Samuel, 17, is in the second grade of senior high school; Adinda, 13, is in the second grade of junior high school; and Metusalak, 7, is in the second grade of elementary school. 

Being a wife who is concerned with family needs, Hesti runs a catering business to generate more income for her family. She sells cakes, cookies, and snacks, such as corn fried, roasted peanuts, cassava chips, and banana chips. The business has been running since 2004. After she produces the products, she usually sells them to the food stall. She also receives orders directly from customers. 

Especially, during the Christmas and New Year celebrations, Hesti receives many orders for cakes, cookies, and snacks. Therefore, she is requesting an individual loan from Tanaoba Lais Manekat Foundation (TLM), amounting to IDR 4,000,000. The loan will be used to purchase an oven, mixer, and ingredients.

loans.use: to purchase an oven, mixer, and snack ingredients.

loans.name: Steven

texts.en: Steven is a 27-year-old single man and works as a private employee. He lives with his parents, named Wilhelmus, 48 and Maria, 40; and two brothers, named Blasius, 17, a 3rd student of Senior High School, and Rahmat, 13, Junior High School student grade 3rd. Steven is a breadwinner in his family. He feels very responsible in giving adequate formal education for his two brothers. Recently, he has applied an individual loan to TLM amounting to IDR 4,000,000. The loan will be spent on school fees and other schooling requirements of his brothers. In addition, the rest of the money will be given to her mother for her catering business capital.

loans.use: to fund school fees and other schooling requirements for his two brothers Blasius and Rahmat.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita is 57 years old and married with three children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock like noodles, sugar, and soap to sell.

Anecita has borrowed and repaid eight loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 20 years and also earns an income from pig fattening and farming rice.

She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock like noodles, sugar, and soap to sell

loans.name: Merly

texts.en:
Merly is 52 years old and married, with two children.

Merly works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and she has requested a PHP 25,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Merly has been in this business for 11 years and has previously received funds through Kiva.

Merly aspires to save enough money to expand her business in order to support the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Annabelle is 44 years old and married with three children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a 29,500 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock like soft drinks, rice, and biscuits to sell.

Annabelle has borrowed and repaid 12 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from gasoline retailing and food vending.

Annabelle aspires to save enough to build a house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock like soft drinks, rice, and biscuits to sell

loans.name: Claudine

texts.en:
Claudine is 24 years old. She is married with one child who is two years old. She sells Irish potatoes and has been in business for five years.

With the loan requested, she would like to buy more potatoes to resell. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest and buy food for home consumption.

loans.use: to buy more potatoes to resell.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria lives in Ermera; she is married and she has one child. She is a business woman. She has been involving in business activities since 2010 with her own working capital of $500. She has very high interest in doing business. She has a small store and she hopes to open a bigger store but her capital is not enough so she is requesting a loan of $800 from Tuba Rai Metin to improve her business. She will used this loan to buy additional items to keep in her store including sugar, milk, cooking oil, biscuits, sardines, soft drinks, candles, slippers and other things to sell. She is taking this loan because she also wants to improve her management for her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy sugar, milk, cooking oil, biscuits, sardines, soft drinks, candles, and slippers to sell.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: $600.00 is offered to Maria to improve her business. Maria lives in Ermera and she is a business woman. Most of her daily income is from selling shoes so she is still happy to do her business. She started to open her business in 2009, with her own working capital of $1000.00. She was going to add money to her principal amount to buy more shoes such as women's shoes, men's shoes, women's slippers, men's slippers and other things to sell Including solar power. It has become her activity so she is happy to do it every day. She is happy with the loan that was offered from Tuba Rai Metin for her to have more working capital to buy more shoes. Maria also cultivates animals like dogs, chicken, pigs and cows.

loans.use: to buy women's shoes, men's shoes, women's slippers, men's slippers and other things to sell Including solar power.

loans.name: Las Maravillosas_74 Group

texts.es:
Gabriela es una mujer de 24 años de edad vive con su pareja, tiene 2 hijos de 2 y 5 años, y su negocio es la venta de refrigerios.
Ella es buena madre, emprendedora, alegre, optimista, feliz, de buena actitud, responsable y trabajadora. Su negocio lo realiza de forma ambulante en la zona ‘la mutualista’ un área comercial ubicada en el centro de la ciudad caracterizada por agrupar a la mayor parte de oficinas comerciales y de empresas. De clima cálido, tropical y húmedo a una temperatura que varía durante el día entre aproximadamente 21-35 grados centígrados.
Gabriela es de tez morena, cabello negro largo amarrado, su lengua materna es el Guaraní que comparte con su familia, para el comercio habla español (la 2 de la derecha, usa blusa roja). Su vida la realiza con su pareja que se dedica a la construcción y con sus hijos ambos todavía no están en edad escolar y juegan todo el día. La necesidad por darle un futuro mejor a sus hijos la llevó a liderar una banca de personas con negocio como; confección de carteras de cuero, venta de salteñas, confección de polleras, servicio de transporte, tienda de videos, venta de vajillas y venta de celulares, para solicitar un préstamo y continuar con sus actividades. Su negocio es la venta de refrigerios a personal de oficinas dentro de  sus trabajos en horario de descanso; ella se encarga de preparar sándwiches de queso con mortadela, también de huevo, pollo, y otros como hamburguesas y sándwich de carne, durante el descanso a media mañana y a media tarde, entregando su producto debidamente empaquetado. “reparto sándwiches a oficinas de empresas, comercios y me hacen el pedido para el siguiente descanso, retorno a mi casa y lo preparo, es un trabajo de tiempo completo…” comenta. Su sueño es abastecer de su comida a todas las oficinas y locales comerciales en horario de descanso. Ella desea realizar la ampliación de su negocio mediante la compra de una conservadora de alimentos portátil para transportar la comida refrigerada hasta sus clientes. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 4 años que viene desarrollando esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Gabriela solicita un préstamo para la compra de una conservadora de alimentos portátil para transportar alimentos hasta sus clientes
texts.en:
Gabriela is 24 years old, she lives with her partner and she has 2 children aged 2 and 5. She sells snacks.
She is a good mother, a resourceful, friendly, happy, optimistic woman with a good attitude towards life, and she is responsible and hardworking. She is a street vendor and she works in “La Mutualista”, a commercial area located in the city center, where the greater part of shops and offices can be found. The climate here is tropical and the weather hot and humid, and temperatures vary during the day between 21 and 35 °C approximately.*
Gabriela is dark complexion, she has long, black hair she wears tied back and her native language is Guaraní: she speaks it with her family, and she speaks Spanish when she is at work (she is the 2nd from the right, wearing a red blouse). She shares her life with her partner, who works in construction, and with her children, who do not yet go to school and play all day long. In order to grant a better future for her children, she decided to lead a group of people running activities such as fashioning leather briefcases, selling meat pies, fashioning skirts, offering transportation services, running a video shop, selling dishes and selling mobile phones: they have all come together to ask for a loan to carry on with their activities. Gabriela sells snacks to office workers during their lunch breaks. She prepares cheese and mortadella, egg, chicken and meat sandwiches as well as hamburgers to offer them during the mid-morning and mid-afternoon breaks, carrying her product duly packed. She says “I distribute sandwiches to offices and shops and they place order for the following break: I get back home and prepare them, it’s a full time job…” She dreams of supply all the offices and shops with her food during their breaks. She want to expand her activity by buying a portable freezer to transport fresh food to her customers. This is her first loan cycle with our institution in the 4 years she has been engaging in her activity.
For the reasons above Gabriela is requesting a loan to buy a portable freezer, in order to carry her food to her customers.

<i>*Approximately between 70 and 95 °F<\i>

loans.use: To buy a portable freezer.

loans.name: Everth  Yamir

texts.es: Everth es soltero, no tiene hijos, y labora como maestro de educaciòn secundaria en colegio de la comunidad donde habita, este joven vive con sus padres. Actualmente se presento a Ceprodel para solicitar el financiamiento numero cuatro ya que tiene la necesidad de ponerle piso a su casa donde habita ya que es de tierra y le quiere poner ceramica, dicho financiamiento lo invertiria en la compra de  cemento y ceramica, lo que vendria a mejorar las condiciones de vida  en su hogar
texts.en: Everth is single with no children.  He works a secondary education teacher in the community college where he lives.  He lives with his parents.  Recently he showed up at Ceprodel to request loan number four since he needs to put down a floor in the house where he lives because it is dirt and he wants to put down tile.  He will invest this loan in the purchase of cement and tile which will improve the living conditions in his home.

loans.use: to buy cement and tile.

loans.name: Cecile

texts.en:
Cecile is 29 years old and married with four children.

She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Cecile is borrowing 9,000 PHP through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Cecile has been farming rice for five years and also earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Celsa

texts.en:
Celsa works hard to support her family. Celsa is single and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Celsa requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks like biscuits, soft drinks, sardines, etc. to sell.

Celsa has been in this business for 10 years now. She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

In the future, Celsa would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks like biscuits, soft drinks, and sardines to sell.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria has been involved in business activities since 2008. She started her business with her own working capital of USD 300. She also cultivates animals, like pigs, chickens, dogs, and cows. Maria is married and her husband is a businessman. 

Maria has a shop/store in her house. So, she is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 from Tuba Rai Metin because she wants to buy additional supplies, including slippers, sugar, aqua, cooking oil, soap, coffee, sardines, salt, notebooks, soft drinks, hard drinks, and other things to sell. She is happy because, with the loan from Tuba Rai Metin, she can build her business bigger in the future and her income can be increased.

loans.use: to buy slippers, sugar, aqua, cooking oil, soap, coffee, sardines, salt, notebooks, soft drinks, hard drinks, and other things to sell.

loans.name: Rosabeth

texts.en:
Rosabeth is 46 years old and has four children. She is married and all of her children are in school.

Rosabeth is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 19,500 loan through NWTF in order to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Rosabeth has been raising pigs for six years now, and has borrowed 12 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Rosabeth would like to build and expand her business in order to support the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is 39 years old and married with four children. With two children in school, Marilou works very hard to provide for them.

Marilou runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell.

Marilou has been in this business for six years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap, noodles, and other groceries. 

In the future, Marilou would like to build and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Brian

texts.en:
Brian is 25 years old and single. He has been in the bakery business for five years.

This is his 2nd loan term from VisionFund Kenya and he plans to use the money to buy building materials to construct a house. He will use the anticipated profits to expand his business by buying baking flour, sugar and cooking oil.

His hope for the future is to open another bakery and thus improve his living standards.

loans.use: To buy building materials to construct a house.

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Hello! Meet Janeth, a very hard-working farmer living on a piece of land in Eldoret where she has cows, poultry, and maize. She sells her products in the local market, which is her main source of income and enables her to take care of her children. 

Janeth wants to venture into horticultural farming, which she believes will boost her income as this is an area for which it is easy to find markets. Therefore, she has taken this KIVA loan to boost her horticultural farming. With this loan, she believes that she will be able to accomplish this project, thereby earning more income. She hopes that her family will live comfortably and her children will go to good schools.

You can help this woman improve her farming business and provide for and educate her children. Help her out!

loans.use: To start horticultural farming.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more bales of secondhand clothes for sale

loans.name: Lami Simon

texts.en: Lami Simon is a maize farmer from Kiyawa village in Kaduna state. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Lami Simon would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for her immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Lami Simon can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more than the market price at harvest. Lami Simon, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for her family, and hopes to ensure her children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating the pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Nyarukoni Farmers Association Group

texts.en:
Vincent is a member of Nyarukoni Farmers Association Group, where members pledge to guarantee other members while taking loans. His business is selling the local brew commonly known as waragi. This is a business he started with the aim of generating income. 

He will use the loan facility to buy more local brew to sell. Vincent faces a difficulty of the price changes of alcohol and the high license fees charged on people dealing in the alcohol business.

loans.use: to buy more local brew to sell.

loans.name: Bunu Development Group

texts.en:
Susan is a married woman with children. She is a new client who lives in Kireka Wakiso District.

Susan owns a market stall in the city center where she sells fruits like tomatoes, carrots, cucumber, and many others. She was inspired by her fellow group members to join UGAFODE Microfinance, and she attributed her joining the group to the good interest rates of UGAFODE Microfinance. For those reasons, she requested a loan of 500,000 UGX to buy more of the supplies of fruits to add to her business since she expects the sells to he higher this season and she is assured of more profit. 

The sixth lady at the extreme right is the UGAFODE credit staff in charge of the group.

loans.use: to buy more fruits to expand her business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: for paying PV systems installed in their houses.

loans.name: Milenka Teresa

texts.es:
La socia continua dedicándose a trabajar para una empresa privada, la socia agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir de manera disciplinada con los pagos de las cuotas, la socia lleva buen tiempo trabajando para dicha empresa, la socia está contenta ya que le va bien y ella desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta manera la socia poder continuar apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de un electrodoméstico.
texts.en: The member continues to make a living working for a private business. She gives thanks for the support that she will receive. In addition, she is committed to repaying her loan in a disciplined manner. The member has been working for said private business for a long time. She is happy because she is doing well. She wishes to continue working so that she can continue supporting her family. The member is requesting a loan to buy a household appliance.

loans.use: to buy a household appliance.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cereals

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 40 years old, and married together with her spouse they have been blessed with six children. She has a grocery and cereals business and she has been running it for 15 years now.

This is her first loan cycle from VisionFund Kenya and she plans to use the loan to buy more stock of tomatoes, onions and cereals for sell in her business. She will use the profits to expand her business and to support her children by providing for their needs. 

Her future hopes are to expand her business and be successful.

loans.use: To buy more stock of tomatoes, onions and cereals for sell in her business.

loans.name: Islam

texts.en:
Islam has been in the retail cart business since February 2013. “I like making shirts and designing them,” he says. Originally from Egypt, Islam moved to the US about four years ago. He lives with his wife and continues to support his parents in Egypt.

Islam’s cart lets customers pick a plain t-shirt, sweatshirt, or hooded jacket, and then add any picture, logo, or text they want. Islam’s designs include humorous pictures and sayings, as well as sports-related themes.

Islam currently works out of a mall in Maryland. With the holiday season coming, Islam expects higher foot traffic in the mall, and more customers will decide that one of his shirts would make a great, customized gift for a loved one.

He needs a loan to purchase t-shirts, hooded sweatshirts, and other supplies to make sure he can meet this increased demand.

loans.use: to purchase t-shirts and hooded sweatshirts for the holiday season.

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher used the previous loan to buy local brew to sell. 

He is a married man with six children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He has a dream of educating his children up to tertiary level and having a fully stocked business. 

Christopher has been in the motorcycle business and the sector has helped him to promptly provide basic needs for his family. However, he wishes to diversify his income sources so he has ventured into the local brew trade since it is very lucrative. 

Christopher needs a loan to buy waragi (local brew) to sell.

loans.use: to buy waragi (local brew) to sell.

loans.name: Ma. Helen

texts.en:
Ma. Helen is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

She is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF in order to buy more fish to sell for her fish vending business.

Ma. Helen successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

NWTF is re-listing Ma. Helen's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila is 30 years old and married with two children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Mila has a dried fish-vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 12,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy more dried fish to sell.

Mila has been in this business for twelve years. In the future, Mila would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Charito

texts.en:
Charito is 55 years old and married with three children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks like sardines, noodles, and rice to sell.

Charito has borrowed and paid 5 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 20 years and also earns an income from food vending.

Charito aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks like sardines, noodles, and rice to sell.

loans.name: Jay-Ann

texts.en:
Jay-Ann is 27 years old and married with five children. Three of her children are in school.

Jay-Ann works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase additional stocks of groceries to sell.

Jay-Ann has borrowed and paid twelve loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for seven years and also earns an income from raising livestock.

Jay-Ann aspires to save enough money so she can continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of groceries to sell.

loans.name: Maria Yamileth

texts.es: Doña Maria combina su tiempo entre su carrera de docencia y su negocio de librería, hace cuatro años que inicio en el negocio y hasta el momento le ha ido muy bien con el apoyo de su papa y sus hijos. Tiene dos hijos que aun están a su cargo porque asisten a la escuela. Solicita el crédito para comprar cuadernos, lapiceros, marcadores, borradores, reglas entre otros y así invertir más ya que es la temporada escolar. De esta manera lograra maximizar sus ventas y obtener mejores ganancias.
texts.en: Maria splits her time between her teaching career and her bookstore business.  She started her business four years ago and it has been going well with the support of her father and children.  She has two children for whom she is still responsible because they attend school.  She is requesting the loan  to buy notebooks, pens, markers, and erasers amongst other things since it is school time.  In this way, she will be able to maximize her sales and get better profits.

loans.use: to buy notebooks, pens, markers, erasers, and rulers amongst other things.

loans.name: Titukulane Group

texts.en: Sella is aged 31 and has six children whose responsibility lies in her hands. She sells usipa (small fish) in order to adequately support her family, but despite these efforts, life is still a struggle for her. As such, she decided to take out a loan so she could sufficiently meet the needs of her family’s members by being able to pay their medical bills and school fees.  She will use the loan to expand her business by purchasing more stock. She plans to build a better house for her family members. Although she still faces some minor challenges, accessing loans have improved her living standards as she is now able to provide food for her family members.

loans.use: To buy fish

loans.name: Vicent

texts.en:
Vicent is a well-known farmer mainly dealing in tea farming at Swazi 11 village in Kyamuhunga-Busheny District. He started this tea project in September 2001, and he has managed to sustain his family of six children. He also trades in coffee as another source of income to support his family. He is married, and his children are aged 10, 7, 5, and 3. Two are in school. 

He has applied for a loan of 1,500,000 UGX to buy fertilizers for maturing his tea garden to increase the yields. With an increase in yields, he hopes to earn more income for his family's needs. He is an honest man at work, and he works for 10 hours a day. He sells to tea factories around Bushenyi District. He is faced with the challenge of too much rain that affects the harvest. His dream is to build a good and big house. He is grateful for the services and looks forward to a long lasting partnership. Pictured is Vicent and his wife carrying their child in their banana plantation.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: pay for her husband's taxi maintenance.

loans.name: Kisa Kya Mukama Wamala Group

texts.en:
Margret is a single mother with children that she takes care of single-handledly. She is a repeat client has so far acquired six loans from UGAFODE Microfinance. She is grateful to Kiva lenders because her previous loans enabled her to expand her retail and wholesale shop. She is grateful to the low interest rates and the long repayment period of UGAFODE.

Margret is taking a loan of 4,000,000 shillings to expand on her retail and wholesale shop. With this, she is hopeful she will further expand her business and therefore increase her sales and profit. 

She is hard working and thanks Kiva lenders and UGAFODE for being there for her and her group in times of financial need. The extra person in the photo on the extreme right is the UGAFODE staff member.

loans.use: to buy more goods such as soda, beer, sugar, and rice for her business.

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en: Nasreen is a 46-year-old, married woman. She is a mother of six children. Her husband has had a business selling and purchasing animals for many years. Nasreen fully supports and assists her husband with his work. Now, she has requested a loan of 45,000 PKR. She wants to use this loan amount to purchase more cattle to resell on the market. She wants to improve her standard of living through all her efforts.

loans.use: to purchase more cattle to resell on the market.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sugar, noodles, eggs, milk, candies, seasoning, vegetables, notebooks and other things to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a clean cook stove

loans.name: Doña Lidia Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario Doña Lidia está integrado por tres microempresarias laboriosas, coordinado por Maria Elena de 28 años de edad, soltera, propietaria de una Pulpería desde hace tres años, el crédito lo solicita para la compra de papel higiénico, toallas sanitarias, aceite, granos básicos, gaseosas, jugos cítricos, etc. Con los financiamientos anteriores ha logrado la compra de una refrigeradora con el fin de aumentar las ganancias y fidelidad de los clientes. La segunda socia es la señora Maria de los Ángeles de 40 años de edad, y es propietaria de una pulpería desde hace nueve años en su domicilio y Doña Sandra tiene 38 años de edad y se dedica a venta de productos varios.
texts.en:
The Doña Lidia solidarity group is made up of three hardworking micro entrepreneurs, coordinated by Maria Elena. She is 28 years old, single and has owned a grocery store for three years. She is applying for a loan to buy toilet paper, sanitary towels, oil, basic grains, soft drinks, citrus juices, etc. With previous financing she was able to buy a refrigerator in order to increase profits and the loyalty of her customers. 

The second member is Maria de los Ángeles, who is 40 years old and has run a grocery store from her home for nine years. Sandra, is 38 years old and makes a living selling various products.

loans.use: to buy toilet paper, sanitary towels, oil, basic grains, soft drinks, citrus juices, etc. and ba able to increase sales.

loans.name: Zahraa

texts.en:
Zahraa is a 24-year-old Lebanese married woman living with her two children and her husband, who runs a barbershop. Her husband is a hard worker, and he is the main income source for the family.

Recently, she started to work at her domicile as a private teacher. She is a very welcoming person and treats her students in a friendly way.

Currently, she is eager to borrow a youth loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l., as she wants to purchase a laptop with the purpose of extending her background and making her preparations easier to complete.

loans.use: to purchase a laptop.

loans.name: Esmeralda 2 - 27 Group

texts.es:
Zenovia es una mujer de 44 años de edad, casada, tiene 3 hijos varones de 18, 16 y 9 años, y su negocio es la venta de artesanía para pared.
Ella es buena madre, emprendedora, alegre, optimista, feliz, de buena actitud, responsable y trabajadora. Su negocio lo realiza de forma ambulante en ferias como la ‘Alasita’ que es una feria artesanal, cuya característica principal es la venta de miniaturas con la finalidad ritual de que las mismas se conviertan en realidad. La deidad Aymará ‘Ekeko’ es el objeto principal de la feria.
Zenobia es de tez morena, cabello negro largo trenzado, su vestimenta es tradicional (sombrero, manta y pollera), su lengua materna es el Aymará y habla español por cultura general y por el comercio que realiza (sentada al centro, usa sombrero). Su vida la comparte con su esposo que se dedica al transporte y con sus hijos que estudian en la escuela, viven en una casa alquilada construida de ladrillo que cuenta con agua potable, electricidad y alcantarillado. Debido a la necesidad de ampliar su negocio formó una banca de personas con negocios como; artesanía en yeso, venta de refrescos, librería, venta de ropa, venta de fruta, venta de tomates y confección de tejidos,  para solicitar un préstamo y ampliar sus negocios. Su negocio es la venta de artesanía para pared como; zampoñas de yeso, cuadros de madera tallada, gaviotas de bronce, flores secas, platos de barro cocido, fotos talladas, etc. Negocio que realiza de forma ambulante en diferentes ferias y mercados de la ciudad y de otras ciudades, viajando constantemente. Su negocio es rentable porque siempre consigue novedades o artículos de moda, su principal problema es el peso de su mercadería porque debe transportarla por diferentes ciudades. “La Alasita es una fiesta cultural que une a todo el país…” comenta. Su sueño es tener una casa propia. Ella desea realizar una inversión en su negocio mediante la compra de artesanía para pared por mayor para ofertar en la siguiente feria de Alasitas. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 10 años que viene realizando esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Zenovia solicita un préstamo para la compra de artesanías de pared para ofertar en la próxima feria de Alasitas.
texts.en:
Zenobia is a 44 year old woman, married, and has three sons who are 18, 16, and 9 years old.  Her business is the sale of wall art. She is a good mother, entrepreneur, cheerful, optimistic, happy, of good attitude, responsible, and hardworking. Her business is done by traveling in fairs like the ‘Alasita’, which is a craft fair whose main principal is the sale of miniatures - the ritual being that the miniatures represent a real item to be acquired in the future.  The Aymará deity 'Ekeko’ is the main subject of the fair. "The 'Alasita' is a cultural festival that unites the whole country...", she says. 

Zenobia has dark skin, long black braided hair, her dress is traditional (hat, blanket, and skirt), her mother tongue is Aymará and she speaks spanish for general culture and for the trade that she carries out. She is seated at center, wearing a hat. Her life is shared with her husband, who makes a living in transport, and with their children studying in school. She lives in a rented house made of brick that has safe drinking water, electricity, and sewage system.

Due to her need to expand business, she formed a bank of people with other businesses such as: plaster crafts, soft drink sales, book sales, clothing sales, fruit sales, tomato sales, and weaving.  This group is asking for a loan together to expand their businesses. Her business is the sale of wall art like plaster pan pipes, carved wooden boxes, bronze seagulls, dried flowers, fired clay plates, carved pictures, etc. Since her business is carried out by traveling in different fairs and markets of the city and to other cities, she is constantly traveling. Her business is profitable because she always gets new or fashionable items. Her main problem is the weight of her merchandise because it needs to be transported to different cities. 

Her dream is to have her own house. She wants to invest in her business by purchasing wholesale wall art to offer in the next Alasitas fair. This is her first sequence of loans with the institution in the 10 years that she has been doing this activity. It is for these reasons that Zenobia asks for a loan for the purchase of wall art to offer in the next Alasitas fair.

loans.use: to purchase wall art to offer in the next Alasitas fair.

loans.name: Bright Group

texts.en:
Bertha, who is in her mid-30s is married with two children who are still in school. She has been running electronic money transfer business for four years now. She works from 7:30am to 7pm daily and is able to make a very good monthly profit.

This will be another loan from Tujijenge Tanzania for Bertha. She used the previous loans to open a grocery store, increased on tigo pesa, m-pesa and has started selling air tail money. She has managed to pay back all her loans successfully. She is happy with the loan because she can take her children to good schools and is living a comfortable life. She appreciates Kiva for their support. She used the profit to pay school fees and covered household expenses. 

She will use this loan to buy more electronic money transfer to meet her customers' demand. She dreams of signing a partnership with an electronic transfer company.

Bertha will share this loan with her loan group "Bright Group" which consist of four members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more electronic money transfer to meet her customers' demand.

loans.name: Ephantus

texts.en:
Ephantus, aged 31, is married and, together with his wife, has been blessed with three young children. He sells bags, a business that he has operated for the last 12 years, earning a monthly income of Kshs. 60,000.

Ephantus has requested his first loan of Kshs.10,000 from VisionFund Kenya which he will use to buy stocks of bags to sell. With the anticipated profits, he will be able to repay his loan.

His hopes and dreams for the future are to add more stocks of bags to sell.

loans.use: to buy stocks of bags to sell

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 28 years old. He is married and together with his wife they have been blessed with 2 children.

Emmanuel is in the transport business via a motorcycle, a business he has done for the last 8 years, earning a monthly income of 100,000 KES.

Emmanuel has requested his 3rd loan with VisionFund Kenya of 108,000 KES, which he will use to buy a new motorcycle. He successfully repaid his previous loans.

With the anticipated profits, Emmanuel will be able to have a successful business and happy family.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to build another classroom

loans.name: Merenciana

texts.en:
Merenciana is 51 years old and married with five children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Merenciana is borrowing PHP 8,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Merenciana has been in this business for two years and also earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream, which is to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cattle to resell.

loans.name: Kaka Yohana

texts.en:
Kaka Yohana is a maize farmer. Before she joined Babban Gona, Kaka Yohana had to sell her maize at low prices soon after harvest to cater for her immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Kaka Yohana can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Kaka Yohana is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for her family and hopes to make more money for herself and her family.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 27 years old. He is married with two children aged between one and three and who are not yet in school. He is a farmer and has been farming for six years. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy fertilizers of maize for sale. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption. 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: buy fertilizers of maize for sale.

loans.name: Arsenia

texts.en:
Arsenia is 54 years old and a widow with nine children. Four of her children are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.  

Arsenia has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more fish to sell.

Arsenia has been in this business for ten years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for fitness equipment.

loans.name: Rosaura

texts.es: Rosaura tiene 35 años de edad y habita en casa propia junto a su compañero de vida y su hijo de 16 años de edad y su hija de 6 años de edad. Rosaura posee una pequeña pupuseria y una tienda en su hogar de residencia. Estos negocios son sus principales fuentes de ingresos y es así como lleva el sustento a su hogar. Con el deseo de mejorar sus ventas e ingresos ha tomado la decisión de solicitar este crédito a FUSAI para comprar variedad de productos de tienda como: azúcar, arroz, frijoles, aceite, detergente, leche, golosinas, etc.
texts.en:
Rosaura is 35 years old and lives in her own home together with her life partner, her 16-year-old son and her 6-year-old daughter. Rosaura owns a small pupusa shop and store in her home. These businesses are her primary sources of income and in this way Rosaura is able to support her household. 

Wishing to achieve increased sales and income, she has decided to apply for this loan through FUSAI in order to buy a variety of products for the store including: sugar, rice, beans, oil, detergent, milk, candy, etc.

loans.use: to buy: sugar, rice, beans, oil, detergent, milk, candy, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for enrollment and monthly tuition payments for her children's school.

loans.name: Felix

texts.en:
Felix is 40 years old. He is married and together with his wife, they have been blessed with two young children.

Felix is a farmer, a business he has done for the last 21 years, earning a monthly income of KES 24,000.

Felix has requested his second loan of KES 20,000 from VisionFund Kenya, which he will use to buy more chickens for resale. He successfully repaid his previous loan.

With the anticipated profits, Felix will be able to fully educate his children.

His hopes and dreams for the future are to produce high yields as well as educate his children.

loans.use: to buy more chickens for resale

loans.name: Unidos Al Futuro Group

texts.es: “UNIDOS AL FUTURO” es un grupo conformada por mujeres trabajadoras y responsables con sus cuotas de grupo. Sabina tiene 58 años de edad es casada con hijos independientes. Ella implemento su bodega en su vivienda en el cual ofrece abarrotes verduras carnes bebidas y a la vez vende gas y cerveza. El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de mas productos abarrotes cerveza gas bebidas. El grupo agradece a los inversionistas KIVA por el crédito brindado. Sabina es la segunda persona parada del lado derecho viste blusa beige.
texts.en: “UNIDOS AL FUTURO” is a group made up of women workers who are responsible with their group fees. Sabina is 58 years old and married with independent children. She installed her grocery store in her home, in which she provides groceries, vegetables, meat, drinks, and also sells beer and gas. The loan will be invested in purchasing more products (groceries, beer, gas, and drinks). The group is grateful to Kiva investors for providing the loan. Sabina is the second person from the right, wearing a beige blouse.

loans.use: with the purchase of more groceries, beer, gas, and drinks

loans.name: Everline

texts.en:
Wonderful Kiva lenders! The above picture presents Everline, a small-scale farmer who lives in the remote village of Maili Saba in the Kitale area of Kenya. She is happily married and is blessed with six children. For the last nine years, Everline has been engaged in mixed farming and has never looked back; she really likes what she does. Her primary sources of income have been sales of milk, eggs and crops as well as some personal business in which she engages to make ends meet. Everline finds farming very fulfilling and agrees with the notion that farming is a very profitable business venture. 

However, she constantly faces the challenge of poor productivity on her farm owing to a lack of farm inputs. She is seeking a loan to buy farm inputs such as quality seeds and fertilizer that will increase her production levels which will immediately translate into increased income levels. Everline is a very hard-working woman who believes that, through hard work and honest sweat, her living conditions will permanently change. She will use the extra income she will receive to repay the loan and increase her farming business.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs such as quality seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Mechelle

texts.en:
Mechelle, aged 22, is a woman with two children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur who has had a food vending business in the Philippines for the past year. 

Mechelle has requested a PHP 4,500 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. In the future, she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie, aged 37, is a married woman with four children, two of whom attend school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur and has had a buy-and-sell coconut wine business in the Philippines for the past two years. 

Melanie has requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional containers of coconut wine to sell. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional containers of coconut wine to sell

loans.name: Libia

texts.es:
La socia Libia continua dedicándose al negocio de venta de autopartes para carros, la socia agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir de manera disciplinada con los pagos de las cuotas, la socia lleva buen tiempo con su negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia continua vendiendo parabrisas, faros entre otros, la socia desea que su negocio crezca.
 
La socia solicita el crédito para comprar parabrisas entre otros.
texts.en: Libia continues to make a living with her business selling spare parts for automobiles. The member gives thanks for the support that she will receive. In addition, she is committed to repaying her loan in a disciplined manner. The member has had said business for a long time. Her business does well as a result of the effort that she puts forth every day. The member continues selling windshield wipers and headlights, among other things. She hopes that her business will grow. She is requesting a loan to buy windshield wipers, among other spare parts.

loans.use: to buy windshield wipers, among other spare parts.

loans.name: Myra

texts.en:
Myra is 30 years old and has four children. Myra is married and three of her children are in school.

Myra is in the agricultural business, farming vegetables in the Philippines. Myra requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Myra has been in this business for two years now and has borrowed one time in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Myra would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Nyame Bekyere Daa Group

texts.en: Safuratu is a 47-year-old woman who stays at Krowfofordo in Assin North District in the central region of Ghana. Safuratu is married with seven children. The children’s ages are 6, 13, 16, 18, 20, 24, and 28 years. Four are now schooling. Safuratu is a cocoa farmer and she has been farming for 20 years now. Safuratu choose farming as her career after she was not able to go to school or learn a trade. She decided to purchase an Elsa Clean Cook Stove after community education on clean cook stoves, indoor/outdoor air quality, and reducing deforestation. Now her main problem is the source of funds to purchase the Elsa Clean Cook Stove. She needs financial assistance to purchase an Elsa Clean Cook Stove, reduce her energy cost, and improve the health her family through safer means of cooking. Safuratu thanks all her microlenders for helping her improve the health of her family and save the forest of her village.

loans.use: To buy a clean cook stove

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is 40 years old and has three children. She is married and all of her children are in school.

Alma is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Alma requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy medicines and vaccines for her pigs.

Alma has been raising pigs for two years now, and has borrowed four times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Alma would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy medicines and vaccines for her pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for marketing collateral.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 40 years old. She is married to Thomas and together they have been blessed with 5 children.

Rose is a farmer; farming is a business she has done for the last 14 years, earning a monthly income of KES 20,000.

Rose has requested for her second loan with VisionFund Kenya KES 15,000, which she will use to purchase farm inputs like fertilizers, seedlings and sprays. She successfully repaid her previous loan.

With the anticipated profits, Rose will be able to educate her children fully.

Her hopes and dreams for the future are to grow her farming business in order to produce high yields.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn, a fish vendor from Concepcion, Iloilo, is 37 years old, married and has five children. Evelyn has been in the fish vending business for more than five years now. She earns an additional income with her husband through their pedal rickshaw transport business.  

Evelyn is requesting a loan to buy more fish to sell and to pay for the repair of their rickshaw. This loan will help improve both businesses. 

In the future, Evelyn hopes to make her business more sustainable and productive. Moreover, she wants to save money for the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell and to pay for the repair of their rickshaw

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac does farming in Thika town and has been in the farming business for 14 years. He is 68 years of age, married, and together with his spouse they have been blessed with 7 children. 

He plans to use this loan to buy fertilizer and seedlings for planting in his farm. He will use the anticipated profits to educate his children. 

This is his first loan term from VisionFund Kenya and his future hopes are to expand his farming business and improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds for planting in his farm.

loans.name: Nancy Violeta

texts.es:
La socia sigue dedicándose al negocio de tienda de abarrotes, la socia agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir de manera disciplinada con los pagos de las cuotas, la socia continua vendiendo diferentes tipos de productos como arroz, azúcar, leche entre otros, la socia desea poder agrandar su negocio, siendo de esta manera que la socia saca adelante a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para comprar gaseosas entre otros.
texts.en: The member continues working in her grocery store business. The member appreciates the support that will be given to her, and in the same way she promises to fulfill, in a disciplined way, the payments of her fees. The member continues selling different types of food like rice, sugar, milk, among other things. The member wants to be able to enlarge her business in order to get her family ahead. The member requests the loan to buy soda, among other things.

loans.use: to buy soda, among other things.

loans.name: Annah

texts.en:
Annah, aged 36, is married and, together with her spouse, has been blessed with three children. She does farming and it has been profitable. 

Annah plans to use this loan to buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer to help with planting on her farm. She will use the anticipated profits to educate her children. 

This is her fourth loan term from VisionFund Kenya after having successfully repaid her previous loans. Annah's future hopes are to expand her business and educate her children.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Teresiah

texts.en: Teresiah is a married woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be focused and disciplined. She operates a retail business where she makes jikos, cooking pans, and other items. Her business is located in an area with lots of clients who buy in wholesale. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the rainy season. She will use the Kes 30,000 loan to buy metal sheets, clay, and other materials to make jikos and cooking pans. She hopes that in the future, she will have a good life and educate her son. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy metal sheets, clay, and other materials to make jikos and cooking pans

loans.name: Seyereye Group

texts.fr:
Constitué de cinq femmes, les membres du groupe Seyereye sont majoritairement  mariées et vie dans des ménages monogamiques. Elles ont en moyenne  d’âge 42 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Kanadjiguila  commune du  Mandé/cercle de Kati. Elles se sont connues à travers des tontines dans le quartier et  leurs activités génératrices de revenu. Les membres du groupe mènent  des activités génératrices de revenu  différent, notamment la vente de, fruits (bananes) de bonnes qualités, lait, tomates, bananes plantains et tubercules. Dans  le but d’élargir et d’agrandir   leurs activités, elles ont décidé de faire recours à  Soro Yiriwaso   et  sont  à leur  3ème  prêt  en solidaire.
Madame Nayouma   (femme arrêtée en 2ème position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo) a une bonne notoriété, car  les fruits très prises par les femmes à Kanadjiguila. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  4 corbeilles de bananes au quartier du fleuve à Bamako. Elles s’approvisionnent au quartier du fleuve à Bamako.  Elle mène ses activités au comptant à Kanadjiguila    à une clientèle  mixtes. Madame Nayouma   compte  réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice moyen de60 000 FCFA par mois, qui sera utilisé, pour satisfaire son besoin et investir le reste dans son activité. Madame a pour objectif de fidéliser  ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’en profiter beaucoup de prêt.
texts.en: The five women that compose the Seyereye group, are mostly married and live in monogamous families. They are, on average, 42 years old and have 5 children. They all live in the Kanadjiguila district of Mandé/Kati Circle. They met through family ties, as well as neighborhood links and from their revenue generating activities. The members of the group has different revenue generating activities, in particular through the sale of good quality fruits (bananas), milk, tomatoes, plantains and tubers. In order to increase their level of activity, they decided to ask for their third loan from Soro Yiriwaso. Mrs Nayouma (seen in the photo as second from the left) has a good reputation, and her fruits are well sought after by the women in Kanadjiguila. She plan to use her loan to purchase four more baskets of bananas from the river neighborhood in Bamako. They stock up at the river market, and sell for cash to a mixed client base. Mrs Nayouma plans to earn an average monthly profit of 60 000 FCFA, in order to satisfy her needs and invest in the remainder of her activity. She hopes to solidify her partnership with Soro Yiriwaso in order to take advantage of the loans.

loans.use: purchase fruits (bananas)

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn is 22 years old and single.

Analyn is in the agricultural business, farming rice in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Analyn has been farming rice for five years now, and she has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Analyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Evalyn

texts.en:
Evalyn is a mother to 3 children, and she is humble and a hard worker. At 37 years old, she fights to get them ahead through education and by providing the example of a good life. Evalyn's efforts and the support of the people she knows allowed her to open her small store 2 years ago and to maintain her weekend food sales, which have made her well known in the area. After visiting and sharing in this family’s poverty, one notices the humility and friendliness of its members, who work as a team to achieve a better quality of life. Her youngest daughter is in third grade and gets excellent marks.

Evalyn's work involves selling food, along with the support of her daughters, has allowed her to fix up the front of her humble home with materials that many consider rubbish. She set up her shelves, racks, work desk and cash register, thus opening up her store to the community. She has established herself through her work and offers fashion merchandise and sandals that are very popular. The business is a group effort of the entire family. With the support of her youngest children, Evalyn sells food on the weekends and tends to the business. The additional income from food sales, shown in her business documents, and the support of her daughters has allowed her to attend to her customers and to offer very high-quality merchandise. The store is located in a poor neighborhood. It is unique in the area, and, in spite of its humble conditions, it is a reference for many people who buy good quality, fashionable clothing. 

This loan will allow Evalyn to purchase and diversify her products, and she wishes to invest in seasonal clothing for New Year's and for summer vacation. Her main objective is to raise her children and support them in school. She wants them to continue studying and to obtain a career, thus improving their standard of living. She dreams of improving her home and her store in the future.

loans.use: To purchase and diversify the products in her clothing shop.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a clean cook stove

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is a married woman with two children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Mary Ann is 26 years old and one of her children is in school.

Mary Ann has a bicycle transport business in the Philippines. It was damaged by Super Typhoon Haiyan November 8, 2013. Mary Ann requested a PHP 5,000 bridge loan through NWTF to buy spare parts and other materials needed to restart her business activities.

Mary Ann has been in this business for two years and would like to rebuild it with your help. In the future, Mary Ann would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy spare parts and other materials needed

loans.name: Fabiano

texts.en:
Fabiano has borrowed a loan of UGX 1,200,000. He is 24 years old and has never taken a loan from UGAFODE He is married and has three children; only two of them are in school. The children are 5, 3 and 2 years old respectively.

He is active in tea growing. He works for 7 hours a day. He started this business in 2008, and his business is located in Bushenyi District. He started this business to raise his family's income and meet their basic needs.

He will use the loan money to buy fertilizer. He sells his harvest to tea traders in factories. His hope is to educate his children. The main challenge he faces is weather changes--the dry season affects his tea project most. He is honest and looks toward a stronger partnership with UGAFODE.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for his tea plantation

loans.name: Robina

texts.en: Robina is a 51-year-old married woman. For many years, she has had a business purchasing and selling animals with the help of her husband. Her business has provided her family with a decent life. She is a mother of five children. She is very motivated to provide them with a beautiful life with good education, food, and clothing. She has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR. She intends to use this loan to purchase more baby goats and calves to cater to more customers to generate greater revenue in the future to meet her household expenses.

loans.use: to purchase more baby goats and calves to cater to more customers to generate greater revenue in the future to meet her household expenses.

loans.name: Indo

texts.en:
Indo is a maize farmer from Dogon Fako village in Kaduna state. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Indo would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Indo can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Indo, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for her family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to cover the cost of her daughter's education.

loans.name: Siguidia Group

texts.fr:
Constitué de quatre femmes, les membres du groupe Siguidia sont équitablement  mariés dans des ménages monogamiques et polygamiques. Elles ont une moyenne  d’âge 43 ans et 6 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Kanadjiguila dans la commune du Mandé / Cercle de Kati. Elles se sont connues à travers des liaisons de parenté, de voisinage et  de leurs activités génératrices de revenu. Les membres du groupe font la vente de, poulets, thés et arachides. Dans  le souci de constituer leurs stocks de vente, les membres du groupe ont décidé de faire recours à  Soro Yiriwaso  et  sont  à leur  3ème cycle de  prêt  solidaire.
Madame Nakan  (femme arrêtée à l’extrême droite sur la photo) a une bonne réputation dans la vente des poulets. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  8 caisses de poulets dans les villages environnants de Bamako. La revente se fait au comptant ou à crédit en ambulant et parfois par commande à une clientèle mixtes. Madame Nakan  compte  réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 60 000 FCFA par mois, qui sera utilisé, pour assurer la scolarisation et les soins de santé des enfants.

loans.use: purchase chickens

loans.name: Jinky

texts.en:
Jinky is a 33-year-old, married woman and a mother of two children, from Iloilo, Philippines. She runs a small sari-sari or retail store business, selling different goods and items to the people in her locality. Jinky has been in the business for more than five years now.

As of this time, Jinky is requesting to avail herself of a loan to buy more stocks to sell, like rice, toiletries, soap, detergents, canned goods, noodles, biscuits, bread, cooking oil, condiments, salt, sugar, soda, and beverages. This loan will enable her to improve her store's inventories and,thus, attract more buyers.

In the future, Jinky hopes to make her business a stable one. Moreover, she wants to save money for the school expenses of her two children.

loans.use: to buy more stocks to sell in her store.

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en:
Mary Jean is 41 years old and married with four children. With two children in school, Mary Jean works very hard to provide for them.

Mary Jean runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 9,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy additional groceries to sell in her store.

Mary Jean has been in this business for two years and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, noodles, and other groceries. 

In the future, Mary Jean would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy additional groceries to sell in her store.

loans.name: Chita

texts.en:
As a married parent of seven children, Chita works hard to support her family.

She has a rice retailing business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from buying and selling rice grains.  Chita is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell for her rice retailing business.

Chita has been sustaining her business activities through her past 11 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Max Arthur

texts.es:
Max es un hombre de 30 años de edad, vive con su pareja, tiene 2 hijas de 2 y 5 años, y trabaja como transportista.
Él es independiente, cuidadoso, responsable y trabajador. Su trabajo lo realiza en la localidad de ‘Sacaba’, un área rural que se mantiene como granero de la ciudad, por la producción de cereales, verduras y frutas, maíz, trigo, cebada, hortalizas, frutilla, plátanos, papayas, naranjas, manzanas, duraznos y hasta plantas de tumbo. Las construcciones del lugar son mayormente antiguas y no cuentan con servicios básicos.
Max es de tez morena, baja estatura, cabello negro corto, su lengua materna es el Quechua que se habla en el lugar y también habla español por cultura general y por el trabajo que realiza. la casa donde vive casi toda su vida perteneciente a su familia, cuenta con electricidad y agua de pozo, la comparte con su pareja que se dedica al comercio de fruta y sus hijos que todavía no están en edad escolar; “me gustaría darle a mi familia un lugar seguro dónde vivir…” comenta. Su sueño es terminar de construir su casa, el desea realizar la instalación de agua potable en su cocina, baño y lavandería. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 6 años que viene construyendo su casa. 
Es por esos motivos que Max solicita un préstamo para la instalación de agua potable en su cocina, baño y lavandería para darle a su familia un lugar seguro donde vivir.
texts.en:
Max, 30, lives with his wife and has two daughters, 2 and 5.  He works as a hauler.
He is independent, careful, responsible, and hard-working.  He works in the locality of Sacaba, a rural area which is like the granary for the city because of the production of cereals; fruits and greens; corn; wheat; barley; vegetables; strawberries; bananas; papayas; oranges; apples; peaches; and even passion fruit.  Construction in the area is mostly older and doesn't have basic services.
Max has brown skin; short, black hair and is short of stature.  His mother tongue is Quechua which he speaks in that place and he also speaks Spanish in the general population and in the work he does.  The house in which he has lived almost all of his life belongs to his family.  It has electricity and well water.  He shares it with his wife, who makes a living selling fruit, and his children who are not yet of school age.  "I would like to give my family a secure place in which to live," he says.  His dream is to finish the construction of his house and he wants to install a running water in his kitchen, bathroom and laundry room.  This is the first sequence of loans in the six years he has been constructing his house.
For these reasons, Max is requesting a loan to install running water in his kitchen, bathroom and laundry room in order to give his family a secure place in which to live.

loans.use: to install running water in his kitchen, bathroom and laundry room in order to give his family a secure place in which to live.

loans.name: Frank

texts.en:
For the last 14 years Frank has been in the green grocery business and earns a monthly income of 20,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES). Frank is married and blessed with two school-going children.

He has applied for his first loan of 30,000 KES from Vision Fund Kenya and intends to use the loan amount to buy more assorted fruits and vegetables for sale.

Frank will use the anticipated profits to provide for his family's basic needs. He hopes to grow his business and be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Sinapi Kuo Group

texts.en: Amina is 58 years old. She comes from Krowfofordo in the Assin North District in the Central Region of Ghana. She is a cocoa farmer and a member of “Sinapi Kuo” group. Amina is divorced. She has three children. The ages of the three children are as follows: 35, 26, and 20 years and only one child is in school. She sells cooked food within her village as another source of income. Amina decided to use an Elsa Clean Cook Stove for her cooking business after she received community education on clean cook stoves, indoor air quality, and reducing deforestation. She needs a microloan to purchase the stove since she would not be able to pay for it upfront. Amina can repay the loan from the income of her food sale and cost savings from the cost of fuel since Amina has the fuel: virgin pellets made within her community as a waste product. She thanks all her microlenders for their generosity.

loans.use: To buy a clean cook stove

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda raises and sells hogs to earn a living. She is a married woman with three grown children. She lives in the town of Ormoc, Leyte. Her husband is a farmer.

She is asking for a loan to buy additional piglets, pig feed, and vitamins and to pay for renovation of the pig pen. Merlinda can now start raising and selling of healthy pigs. In these ways, her income will augment. She can now start paying her loan and other household expenses. 

Merlinda is hoping that someday her hog raising will be successful especially in uplifting their status of living.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets, pig feed and vitamins and pay for renovation of the pig pen

loans.name: Sinia Beatriz

texts.es:
La Joven Sinia de 21  años de edad, vive con su mama  en su casa propia,  se dedica desde hace 5  años al negocio de venta de ropa Interior como braseares, biquinis, bóxer, calcetas, blúmer, etc.   También  vende sandalias playeras y formales.
Sinia vive en una comunidad  de san Lorenzo,  al sur de Honduras,  es una mujer emprendedora con deseos de salir adelante y lucha día con día para mejorar su calidad de vida, está solicitando el préstamo para compra de sandalias, pantalones, blusas, faldas, calzonetas, blúmeres, bóxer, etc. y así tener más variedad de productos para ofrecer a los clientes que la visiten.
Sinia también espera que esta inversión le permita mejorar su calidad de vida, uno de sus su sueño es tener un buen negocio y bien surtido y al mismo  tiempo mejorar su futuro junto a su familia.

San Lorenzo, Honduras-  Diciembre del 2014
texts.en:
Sinia, 21, lives with her mother in her own house.  She has worked in her business selling underwear for five years, including brassieres, bikinis, boxers, socks, and underwear.  She also sells formal sandals and beach sandals.

Sinia lives in a community in San Lorenzo, in the south of Honduras.  She's an enterprising woman with a desire to get ahead, and she strives every day to improve her quality of life.

She's requesting the loan to buy sandals, pants, blouses, skirts, underwear, swimming trunks, and boxers so she has a wider variety of merchandise to sell to the customers who visit her.

Sinia also hopes this investment will allow her to improve her quality of life.  One of her dreams is to have a good, well-stocked business and also to improve her future with her family.

San Lorenzo, Honduras, December 2014

loans.use: to buy sandals, pants, blouses, skirts, swimming trunks, underwear, boxers, etc. for her business

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary has a hardware shop in the town of Nairobi and has been running this business for five years. She is 41 years old and married. Together with her spouse, she has been blessed with three children. 

She will use this loan to buy more stock of cement, pipes and paint to sell. She will use the anticipated profits to expand her business by buying more stock of hardware materials for resale. 

This is her seventh loan term with VisionFund Kenya, and she paid her previous loans successfully. In the future, she hopes to open more hardware businesses and also provide good education for her children.

loans.use: To buy more stock of cement, pipes and paint to sell.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Hello lenders! Meet Martha. She is 41 years old. She comes from Kitale, which is a town in the Rift valley region of Kenya. Martha is a smallholder farmer who keeps dairy cattle and poultry. She is also an entrepreneur engaged in other small personal businesses (sewing business). For the five years that Martha has been doing farming, she finds milking to be the most enjoyable activity. However, she doesn't enjoy cleaning the dairy unit as much. There is no doubting her deep connection to farm animals, as she names and occasionally talks to her animals. Martha is seeking a loan to purchase farm implements. Farming tools are very crucial to all farmers regardless of the nature of the agribusiness they are involved in. With your loan, Martha will acquire farm implements that will make her work in the field much easier and efficient. These benefits will translate to efficiency, improved quality and profits. Additional income as a result will help Martha to foot the high farming costs that keep rising by the day. When asked, "How will this loan benefit your family?," Martha replied, "More income will help me buy more assets and be able to pay school fees for my school going children.”

loans.use: To buy farm implements

loans.name: Mumuli S C C Group

texts.en:
Harriet, a married woman living in Kagadi, Uganda, is aged 43 years. She started operating a retail shop in 2003, alongside farming to boost her income. She wishes to grow her business into a wholesale shop despite a lot of competition that brings about irregularities in her earnings. 

Harriet is requesting a loan to buy more sugar, toothpaste and soap to sell, to shoot the market. She is a member of Mumuli SCC where each member guarantees the other to get a loan since they don’t pledge securities.

The extra person in the photo is a group member who is saving with the group, has guaranteed fellow members but has not taken a loan this time.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, toothpaste and soap to sell.

loans.name: Johnson

texts.en:
Johnson lives with his wife and their four younger children in a rural area located in the western part of Uganda. The village people in this area work raising and selling animals, especially cows.

Johnson works at raising and selling small animals such as goats, sheep and cattle. His business is located at his home where he has a farm. He has more than five years experience in this field and has very good work and personal references in the area.

The loan requested is to buy more cows. This investment will help him to have more variety and productivity. To have a big influence on his business, Johnson plans to increase his stock of animals to meet the various preferences and needs of his local customers. This will generate a higher income and therefore increase his quality of life and that of his family.

loans.use: To buy cows

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
In 1987, Daniel became the sixth born in a humble rural family that practiced farming in Nkachir, Kenya. He was privileged to get a secondary education before he had to drop out and help his family earn a living. 

Today, Daniel runs a two-acre farm which he keeps 1 cow, 4 goats and 17 head of poultry. He also grows food crops and grass for the animals. He has aspirations of growing his business and making more income out of the land by growing more crops and keeping more animals. The biggest challenge he is facing, however, is the lack of adequate capital to expand farm operations. He is not able to employ his current income because it is tied to personal and family obligations.
 
Daniel is seeking a loan to grow more crops on his farm. He loan will enable him to hire labour and purchase farm inputs necessary for the expansion project. Your contribution towards this loan will eventually empower and uplift Daniel's livelihood through provision of more food and income at the end of the season.

loans.use: to plant vegetables

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is fifty-seven. She is a smallholder farmer residing in Nyamira, an agricultural town in the Nyanza region of Kenya. She is arguably among the most successful clients of Juhudi Kilimo, a microfinance institution that deals only with smallholder farmers in rural parts of Kenya. Tomatoes are Florence's flagship produce.

Back in 2000, Florence practiced traditional farming with little knowledge and no financing at all. She was doing only half an acre of maize crop per season. The returns were so meager that she could barely survive. She kept doing maize farming for years without turning a profit until 2008, when she switched to tomato farming and there was light at the end of the tunnel for her. 

Today, Florence is a fully-fledged entrepreneur. She has been provided with technical guidance, training programs and exposure visits. She has already serviced other asset-based loans fully from Juhudi Kilimo! Through the loans, she has acquired high quality dairy cows and farming supplies

To capitalize more on returns from her booming tomato farming business, Florence is seeking a loan of KES 100,000 to build a greenhouse.
