Unlike her competitors, Florence conducts proper soil preparation and uses modern farming techniques to ensure high quality produce. By doing this, she has created a name for herself and a demand for her produce. 

By supporting this loan, you can put into action the enterprising ideas of one Kenyan mother.

loans.use: To construct a greenhouse for tomatoes

loans.name: Benon

texts.en:
Benon is 37 years old and married. He lives with his wife and his two young children in a rural area where the people earn a living in agriculture (coffee, fruits, corn, potatoes, green bananas and green vegetables), breeding livestock, cattle farming and other businesses. 

For five years, he has made a living in farming, especially coffee growing. Additionally he earns a living breeding livestock such as goats and pigs. Benon is a hardworking man with experience in business and with very good personal and work references in the area. He is asking for this loan to invest in buying manure and fertilizers to grow coffee. In this way, he hopes to earn a better income and therefore, improve his quality of life and that of his family.

loans.use: To buy organic fertilizers

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a married woman. She operates a tailoring shop where she makes clothes and sells decoration materials. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in a promising place. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the fluctuation of prices. She will use the Kes 25,000 loan to buy a new tailoring machine. She hopes that in the future, she will be successful. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy a new tailoring machine

loans.name: Hannatu Yohanna

texts.en: Hannatu Yohanna is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Hannatu Yohanna joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her 3 children. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Hannatu Yohanna had to sell her maize at low prices soon after harvest, to meet her immediate cash needs for items such as children's school fees. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Hannatu Yohanna can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Hannatu Yohanna spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to make more money for herself and her family.

loans.use: To pay for her children's school fees and uniforms thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Mary Uwani

texts.en:
Mary Uwani is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Mary Uwani joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her 3 children. 

Before becoming a Babban Gona member, Mary Uwani had to sell her maize at low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs such as children's school fees. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Mary Uwani can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later at prices up to 40% higher. 

When asked, Mary Uwani  spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: to pay for her children's school fees and uniforms thereby eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Samaila

texts.en:
Samaila is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Samaila joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his 2 children.

 Before becoming a Babban Gona member, Samaila had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest, to meet his immediate cash needs for items such as children's school fees. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Samaila can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later at prices up to 40% higher. 

When asked, Samaila spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: To pay for child school fees and uniforms, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: El-Shadai Group

texts.en:
This group is made up of two ladies who live in the same neighborhood and have been together for many years. They belong to a group called El-Shadai and are into the sale of wigs, tea, and noodles.

Yvonne (standing on the right in the photo) is the featured borrower of the group. She studied to the elementary school level and has been selling wigs in the market for five years now. She enjoys doing this job because it is profitable and has earned her many customers.

Together with her friend, they will need a total amount of 2,400 GHS to expand their businesses.

loans.use: to buy wigs to sell to customers

loans.name: Michael Markus

texts.en:
Michael is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Michael joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his 2 children. Before becoming a Babban Gona member, Michael had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest, to cater to his immediate cash needs, such as food and clothing.

With this loan, and Babban Gona’s support, Michael can now store his maize at harvest time, and sell it a few months later at prices up to 40% higher. When asked, Michael spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for children's school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Rijoya

texts.en: Rijoya is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Rijoya joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her 3 children. Before becoming a Babban Gona member, Rijoya had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs such as children's school fees. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Rijoya can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later at prices up to 40% higher. When asked, Rijoya  spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, hoping to ensure her children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: To pay for child school fees and uniforms thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en: Joshua Mato is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Joshua Mato joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his 3 children. Before becoming a Babban Gona member, Joshua Mato had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as children's school fees. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Joshua Mato can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later at prices up to 40 percent higher. When asked, Joshua Mato spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: To pay for child school fees and uniforms, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: La Esquina Group

texts.es:
El nombre de una comunidad de Veracruz, México tiene su origen en un vocablo de origen náhuatl que significa "lugar donde se junta la cañada” que hace referencia a la gran producción de caña de la región. Por las mañanas se logra apreciar el humo de la fábrica azucarera y detrás, a varios kilómetros, el Pico de Orizaba, volcán más elevado del país.

En uno de los barrios de la localidad se formó un grupo llamado “La Esquina” ya que los miembros se reúnen en una esquina justo al lado de la carretera. Las integrantes son:

María -Venta De Abarrotes
Rosalba -Venta De Productos Naturistas
Alma -Venta De Regalos
Catalina -Venta De Ropa
Reyna -Venta De Antojitos
Cecilia -Calzado Por Catalogo
Karla -Venta De Comida
Margarita -Venta De Zapatos
Paula -Venta De Ropa Por Catalogo

Doña María es una mujer emprendedora y carismática, es madre 4 hijos todos ellos casados. Desde hace 20 años ella se ha dedicado a vender abarrotes en su casa, comenta que al principio la tienda estaba cercada con tablas, con el paso del tiempo y con el crecimiento progresivo del negocio logró construir un local de concreto el cual decidió proteger con unos rieles debido a que se encuentra frente a la carretera y en una semi curva. Hace 7 años mientras dormía, un coche se impactó con su tienda provocando daños materiales por eso decidió protegerlo de esa manera. Con las ganancias obtenidas y el sueldo de su esposo, el señor Silverio, dieron estudios a sus hijos y solventaron los gastos del hogar.

María ya ha solicitado otros créditos a VisionFund, los cuales le han ayudado a mejorar su tienda al invertir en arroz, harina, sopa, frijoles, azúcar, leche, atún, mayonesa, galletas, refrescos, huevos, detergente y así ofrecer un amplio surtido de mercancía a sus clientes. Sin embargo, también su esfuerzo la ha mantenido en la preferencia de los clientes, el lugar se encuentra abierto de las 7 am a las 10 pm, claro está que a partir de las 6 pm cierra su reja y deja la cortina abierta por cuestiones de seguridad. María necesita un nuevo préstamo para comprar más mercancía como huevos, arroz, azúcar, aceite, harina, queso y refrescos para satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes quienes afortunadamente siempre le pagan cuando le piden prestado. "Lo mejor de mi actividad es que estoy en casa y puedo disfrutar más tiempo con mis nietos”.

*La fotografía fue tomada en la esquina de la casa donde se hacen las reuniones, la señora María lleva un vestido color naranja.
texts.en:
The name of a community in Veracruz, Mexico has its origin in a native náhuatl word that means “place where sugar cane is gathered” that makes reference to the great production of sugar cane in the region. In the morning, the smoke of the sugar factory is appreciated and several kilometers behind, the Pico de Orizaba, the highest volcano in the country.

In one of the town’s neighborhoods, a group formed called “La Esquina” [The Corner] since the members get together at a corner on the side of the highway. The members are:

María – grocery sales
Rosalba – natural product sales
Alma – gift sales
Catalina – clothing sales
Reyna – snack food sales
Cecilia – footwear by catalogue
Karla – food sales
Margarita – shoe sales
Paula – clothing sales by catalogue

Doña María is an entrepreneurial and charismatic woman. She is the mother of four children, all of whom are married. For 20 years she has worked selling groceries from her home. In the beginning, the store was enclosed with boards. With the passing of time and the progressive growth of the business, she was able to build a store out of concrete, which she decided to protect with some rails because it is located in front of the highway and on a semi curve. Seven years ago, while she was sleeping, a car hit her store, causing material damage. That is why she decided to protect it in this way. With the obtained earnings and with the salary of her husband, el señor Silverio, they paid for their children’s education and covered the expenses of the home. 

María has already requested other loans from VisionFund, which have helped her to improve her store by investing in rice, flour, soup, beans, sugar, milk, tuna, mayonnaise, cookies, soft drinks, eggs, and detergent, and in that way offer an ample supply of merchandise to her customers. However, her effort has also kept her desired by her customers. The store is open from 7am to 10pm, and of course after 6pm she locks the bars and leaves the curtain open for security reasons. María needs a new loan to buy more merchandise like eggs, rice, sugar, oil, flour, cheese, and soft drinks to satisfy the needs of her customers who fortunately always pay her when they ask for an advance. “The best part of my work is that I am at home and I can enjoy more time with my grandchildren.”

*The photo was taken at the corner of the house where they have their meetings. La señora María is wearing an orange-colored dress.

loans.use: to buy: eggs, rice, sugar, oil, flour, cheese, and soft drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy beauty products to sell.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 41 years old. She is married, and together with her husband they have been blessed with three children of 15, 10, and 7 years old. Her spouse is a businessman, and hence provides additional income for his family.

Elizabeth sells computer spare parts and stationery, a business that is earning her a monthly income of KES 15,000. She has requested her third loan with VisionFund Kenya of KES 45,000, which she will use to purchase more stock of computer spare parts and stationery.

With the anticipated profits, she will be able to invest more in her business and also provide for her family's needs. Her hope and dream for the future is to always make profits and investments.

loans.use: To buy computer spare parts and stationary.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is 48 years old, married, and together with her spouse, they have been blessed with three children. She does farming in Thika town and has been in this business for six years. 

Judith plans to use this loan to buy fertilizer and seedlings for planting on her farm. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her children.

This is her first loan from VisionFund Kenya and her future hopes are to expand her farming business and to be successful.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings.

loans.name: Moko Sane Moko Sane Group

texts.en:
These five women come from the same neighborhood and are part of the Moko Sane Moko Sane ("your concern is my concern") Group. They are bound by good social, economic, and business relationships.

They are selling kenkey (cooked corn dough), fish, maize, gari (cassava flour) and assorted detergents. They will need a total loan amount of 7,800 GHS to expand their businesses.

Ernestina is the group's representative. She's standing in the middle of the photograph. She's married and the mother of three children. She's a merchant. Her new loan request for 2,000 GHS will enable her to buy one bag of maize and gari each to sell to customers. The generated profits will enable her to cover her children's food and health needs, but will also help strengthen her savings account with Kiva Field Partner ID Ghana.

loans.use: to buy one bag of maize and gari each to sell

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is a 27 year old. He is married with 2 children aged 1 and 5, one of them attends school. He has farmed for eight years and will use the loan from Kiva to buy fertilizers to grow maize to resell. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to grow maize to resell.

loans.name: Nyomo No Okwe Group

texts.en:
These ladies are part of the group called Nyomo No Okwe (Focus On Blessing) and are into selling secondhand clothing, pastries, noodles, soap and rice. They have known each other for so many years and are still together, living in the same neighborhood.

Christiana is the group representative. She is 45 years old, is a landlady who lives in her own house and she also attended school to the secondary level. She is married to a pastor and they have one dependable child. She has been selling assorted soap and rice for the past four years, which she uses to take care of the family financially.

She is taking this loan amount of 4,000 GHS together with her colleagues, Matilda and Mary. She will use her portion to purchase more soap and rice and sell to her customers.  She is on her fifth loan cycle. They will hold each other responsible for the repayment of the loan.

loans.use: to purchase more soap and rice to sell to her customers

loans.name: Rose Irene

texts.en:
Rose Irene is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy and sell ginger business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy more stock of ginger to sell for her buy and sell ginger business.

Rose Irene has been in this business for 15 years. She earns more income from pig fattening.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy more stock of ginger to sell for her business

loans.name: Gertrudez

texts.en:
Gertrudez is a fifty-year-old married woman with four children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Gertrudez has a buying and selling root crops business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 12,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to purchase more stocks of root crops to sell.

Gertrudez has been in this business for twenty years. In the future, she would like to build and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of root crops to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for extra employees and additional supplies

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel is originally from Macedonia. When he came to the States, he started working in Staples for so many years. After getting experience in the transportation industry, he decided to open his own business. Now he owns a prestigious company named Bucephal USA. He needs a loan of $6,500 to purchase a truck. That truck will improve his revenues by 50% and also will allow the business to acquire more routes.

loans.use: to purchase another truck

loans.name: Ma. Pia

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Ma. Pia works hard to support her family.

She has a buy and sell crabs business in the Philippines, and she also earns additional income from pig fattening.  Ma. Pia is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy crabs to sell for her buy and sell crabs business.

Ma. Pia has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy crabs to sell in her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine and necessary fabrics for sewing

loans.name: Iris Edelina

texts.es:
La Joven Iris Edelina de 21  años de edad, vive con su mama y su abuela  en su casa propia, se dedica desde hace 5 años al negocio de venta de abarrotería, en su negocio vende todo lo relacionado a la canasta básica.
Iris Edelina vive en una comunidad de San Lorenzo al sur de Honduras, es una mujer emprendedora con deseos de salir adelante y lucha día con día para mejorar su calidad de vida. 
Iris Edelina está solicitando el préstamo para compra de productos para surtir la pulpería como pollo, arroz, frijoles, manteca, jabón, frescos, café, agua, harina, huevos, etc. con el apoyo de este préstamo pretende mejorar sus ingresos y también su calidad de vida.
Su sueño es tener un buen negocio bien surtido y al mismo  tiempo mejorar su futuro junto a su familia.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Diciembre del  2014.
texts.en:
Iris Edelina, a young 21 year old woman, lives with her mom and her grandmother in her own house. She has had a grocery store for the last 5 years. She sells everything related to basic need products. Iris Edelina lives in a community in San Lorenzo, south of Honduras. She is an enterprising woman, she wishes to thrive, and she  struggles every day to improve her life.

Iris Edelina is requesting the loan to buy supplies for the grocery store, such as chicken, rice, beans, lard, soap, soft drinks, coffee, water, flour, eggs etc. She wants to improve her income with the loan, and also improve her life.

Her dream is to have a well stocked business, and at the same time improve her family's future. San Lorenzo, Honduras-

December 2014

loans.use: to buy chicken, rice, beans, lard, soap, soft drinks, coffee, water, flour, eggs, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Soren Johery

texts.es:
El Joven Soren de 20  años de edad es soltero y  no tiene hijos que dependen de él, vive en una comunidad de San Lorenzo al sur de Honduras y se dedica desde hace 02 años al negocio del transporte.
Soren  está solicitando su primer  préstamo, necesita comprar llantas para su taxi y hacerle algunas reparaciones y poderles brindar a sus clientes un mejorar atención y calidad de servicio, espera que esta inversión también le permita obtener los ingresos necesarios  para que pueda ayudar a sus padres con los gastos del hogar.
Soren su deseo es comprarse su  taxi propio.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Diciembre del 2014.
texts.en:
Young Soren is 20 years old and single with no dependents. He lives in a community in San Lorenzo, in the south of Honduras, where he has worked for two years in a taxi transportation business.

He is now requesting his first loan. He needs to buy tires for his taxi and also make some repairs to it so that he can offer better service to his clients.

He hopes that this investment will also bring him the income he needs to be able to help his parents with the household expenses.

Soren's wish is to buy his own taxi.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - December 2014.

loans.use: to buy tires and spare parts for his business.

loans.name: Luz Dary

texts.es: Luz, se encuentra domiciliada en un barrio de Barranquilla, ella es una mujer de 40 años de edad, madre de un hijo de ocho años y una hija de doce años, ella está dedicada a su taller de confecciones, el cual funciona desde el año 2004, su idea de negocio surge a raíz de que su mamá siempre trabajó en esta actividad y ella la acompañaba a su lugar de trabajo,  poco a poco aprendió este arte y decidió abrir su taller, en el que ofrece servicio de confección de vestidos para toda ocasión, disfraces, ropa para niño y damas.  Sus clientes se encuentran ubicados en diferentes localidades de la ciudad, ellos están fidelizados con sus servicios, gracias a la calidad y excelentes acabados de sus productos.  Su horario de atención es bastante amplio, ella labora de 9 a.m. a 11 p.m., todos los días, ella está muy comprometida con su trabajo, puesto que su meta familiar es lograr que sus hijos terminen sus estudios y sean unos profesionales, para ello se hace necesario captar más clientes y ampliar la cobertura. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual invertirá en una maquina plana y un fileteadora, lo que es muy importante para la calidad de los productos terminados y la satisfacción de los clientes.
texts.en:
Luz, 40, lives in a neighborhood in Barranquilla.  She's the mother of a son, 8, and a daughter, 12.

She's very dedicated to the tailor shop she has operated since 2004.  Her business idea came from her mother, who always worked in this field, and Luz would go to work with her.  She learned the art little by little and decided to open her shop, where she offers sewing services: dresses for all occasions, costumes, children's clothing, and women's clothing.  Her customers are from different areas of the city and they're loyal to her services, thanks to the quality and excellent finishing touches on her products.  Her service hours are very broad, from 9 a.m. until 11 p.m. every day.

Luz is very committed to her job because her family goal is for her children to finish school and become professionals.  For that she needs to attract more customers and expand her coverage.

Currently she's requesting a Kiva loan, her first financing from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, to invest in a sewing machine and a serger, which is very important for the quality of the finished product and for customer satisfaction.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine and a serger

loans.name: Anna Leah

texts.en:
Anna Leah is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase materials for the repair of her fishing boat for her fishing business.

Anna Leah has been in this business for ten years. She earns additional income from pig-fattening.

Anna Leah has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money, so she could afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to purchase materials for the repair of her fishing boat.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy construction materials and equipment for use.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
As a married mother of seven children, Elvira works hard to support her family.

She has a buying and selling of peanuts business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from pig fattening. Elvira is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF in order to purchase more stock to sell to her customers.

Elvira has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money so she can continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en: Hello, lenders, meet Teresa. She is a smallholder farmer from the Maili Saba location in the Kitale region of Kenya. Teresa enjoys the support her mixed-farming business gets from her husband of 21 years, Juma. She is looking to expand by leveraging her business. Teresa is seeking a loan to purchase more poultry to increase the number from the 18 she already has on the farm. This will ensure that she can cut costs, reduce waste, and increase egg production. She also makes supplementary income from a dairy cow named Lelmet (meaning white headed). Besides livestock farming, Teresa grows food crops such as maize, bananas, and trees. Her plan is to invest this loan in a way that will give her enough income to take care of her four children's basic and educational needs.

loans.use: To buy additional poultry

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is a smallholder farmer based in Maili Saba village in Kitale, Kenya. She stays with her husband Leonard and 3 children on a high altitude, 2 acre, farmland that is fertile for agriculture. She grows maize and vegetables, and keeps dairy animals and poultry.She also engages in some personal business to make ends meet (timber cutting business). She started farming 2 years after getting married 9 years ago. It was a means of helping her husband look after the family. Besides farming, she started planting trees to give the farm an aesthetic appearance. Ever since, she has become a hardened farmer. Josephine is seeking a loan to purchase farm implements. She is going to use the money to purchase modern farm equipment that is in good working condition, efficient, and improved in design and usability. She has opted out of using old tools that are worn out and hectic to use. She believes she is going to realize a better harvest as a result of using better tools. She will use the additional income to provide her family with a better life.

loans.use: To buy farm implements

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy shoes, slippers, hair oils, bags and other things to sell Including electrical wiring, light bulbs, solar power.

loans.name: Daphine

texts.en:
Daphine is a single mother aged 46 years old, and she has six children who she looks after.  he lives in a semi-urban setting with her family and takes care of two other kids who are orphans.

She runs a bar which she has been operating since 2010 where she works seven days a week and each day she works tirlessly. She supplements her income with agriculture, and she started this business so that she can make a living for her children and also a little capital.

She has acquired this loan facility in order to restock the bar as she is expecting high sales in the Christmas season. Her customers are fellow residents in the community. Her dream is to renovate her house and have a nice looking home instead thus improving her standard of living.  Her greatest challenge is people who get drunk and refuse to pay for the drinks. She describes herself as an honest woman who is grateful for the services of Kiva lenders through UGAFODE.

loans.use: to buy drinks to sell in the bar

loans.name: Fabian

texts.en:
Fabian is an enthusiastic, motivated, and multi-disciplined lawyer and teacher who has a knack for business. He was born in 1975. He has one child, who is four years old. He completed his law diploma in 2005 at the University of Zambia. Fabian needs a loan to make his dream of owning his own business a reality. 

Fabian loves his mobile money transfer business because it helps him to provide for his family and requires less supervision. He says the benefits for his customers are that his services are easy to access, available for all social classes, and affordable. Fabian’s biggest business challenge is that banks close early, making it difficult to deposit money. This makes it hard for him to serve his customers on time. For this reason, Fabian has requested his first Kiva loan. 

When he gets the Kiva loan, Fabian will have essential funds to serve his customers. He currently employs one person and would like to employ more people once his business has grown. He currently operates at one location.

Fabian dreams of expanding his business by opening up in more locations that need his service, so that he can reach more people and also create more employment opportunities. He believes that, with more outlets, he will be able to increase his income and that will help him effectively and efficiently attend to his day-to-day business challenges.

loans.use: To grow his mobile money business to grow his customer base

loans.name: Rock Of Ages Group

texts.en:
This group is made up of four people who are part of the Rock of Ages Group. They are very ready to develop their money-earning businesses. For several years, they've all been living in the same area and they maintain good relationships. Their main businesses are selling groceries, slippers, and fresh fish. 

Belinda is the featured borrower of the group. She's the woman standing on far left in the photograph. She's a very focused married woman who has two dependent children in her care. Belinda buys fresh fish, which she smokes and then sells to her neighbors. She has a very large base of clients and wants to satisfy her clients successfully. With her new loan, she intends to buy GHS 400 worth of fish to sell to her customers. She intends to use her profits to improve the standard of living of her family and ensure that her children get a better education. 

The group will need a total amount of GHS 2,200 to maintain their businesses at this level.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish to smoke and sell

loans.name: Okyeso Nyame Group

texts.en:
These two women and three gentlemen come from the same neighborhood and are part of the Okyeso Nyame Group. The name of their group means 'God of riches.' They are bound by good social, economic, and business relationships. They are selling electrical parts, car spare parts, rubber products and ready-made dresses. They will need a total loan amount of GHS 6,700 to expand their businesses. 

Andrews is the group's representative. He's standing second from the right in the photograph. He's married and the father of a boy. He's a merchant. His new loan request of 1,500 GHS will enable him to buy assorted electrical parts and sell them to customers. The generated profits will enable him to cover his child's food, fees and health needs, and will also help strengthen his savings account with Kiva Field Partner ID Ghana.

loans.use: To buy assorted electrical parts and sell them to customers.

loans.name: Minda

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Minda works hard to support her family.

She has a buy and sell of vegetables business in the Philippines and earns additional income from farming rice and running her general store.  Minda is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy fruits and vegetables to sell in her food stall for her buy and sell of vegetables business.

She successfully repaid her previous loans and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Minda has been sustaining her business activities through her past 16 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to sell in her food stall

loans.name: Elena Alexandra

texts.es: Elena es madre soltera ella tiene 22 años de edad, su hijo tiene 4 años y ya asiste al inicial de la escuelita, Elena trabaja en el campo y sus ingresos los obtiene de el trabajo en la agricultura y de la crianza de animales menores, el crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de cuyes para tenerlos en cuyeras que  desea readecuarlas para que le alcance a criar mas cuyes, la aspiración de este Elena es que crezca su negocio y seguir trabajando para su hijo.
texts.en:
Elena, 22, is a single mother.  Her son is four years old and already attends pre-school.

Elena works in the country and earns her income from agriculture and raising small animals.  She's going to invest the loan in buying guinea pigs to have them in a pen that she wants to renovate so she can raise more guinea pigs.

Elena hopes her business grows and that she can keep on working for her son.

loans.use: to buy guinea pigs

loans.name: Mairamkul

texts.ru: Майрамкул, 52 года, замужем, мать 3 детей. У Майрамкул среднее образование, работает сортировщицей фасоли. Также в качестве дополнительного дохода для своей семьи она вместе с супругом занимается животноводством и полеводством. Благодаря упорному труду Майрамкул, ее хозяйство на сегодняшний день насчитывает 2 коровы, 20 овец. Также есть 2,50 ГА собственной земли, где Майрамкул выращивает фасоль. На ежедневной основе реализует молоко. Бизнес в целом приносит до 8,000 сом (KGS) в месяц. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Майрамкул обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на увеличение поголовья скота за счет покупки овец для откорма и перепродажи. Доходы от кредита Майрамкул планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, постройку сарая для скота.
texts.en: Mairamkul is 52 years old, married and a mother of 3 children. Mairamkul has a secondary education and works as a beans sorter. Also, to provide additional income for her family, she and her husband are involved in animal husbandry and farming. Thanks to Mairamkul's hard work, today she has 2 cows and 20 sheep. She also has 2.50 hectares of owned land, where she grows beans. She sells milk on a daily basis. Altogether, the business yields about 8,000 som (KGS) per month. In order to further develop her business, Mairamkul requested a loan in the amount of 100,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to increase her livestock headcount by buying sheep for fattening up and resale. Mairamkul plans to invest the earnings from the loan into further increasing her livestock headcount and building a barn for livestock.

loans.use: to purchase additional sheep for fattening up and resale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy rice, beans, flours, cooking oil and salt for her food stall

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is 45 years old. She is married and has two children aged 22 and 20. In 2000, she established her vegetable farming business. Working seven days a week and four hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid six loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buys seeds and fertilizers. In the future, Rita plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. 

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer. With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Saidamoh

texts.ru: Эту девушку мастерицу зовут Саидамох. Она предоставляет услуги швеи и имеет в этой сфере 10-летний опыт. Саидамох хотя и 28 лет, но она еще не замужем и живет с матерью, отцом, братьями и невесткой. Ей было 18 лет когда она начала свой швейный бизнес и за эти годы приобрела своих постоянных клиентов. Саидамох шьет профессионально и ее сшитые заказы пользуются успехом. Сейчас Саидамох хотела бы расширить свое дело. Она на заемные средства намерена купить компьютерную швейную машинку, а также необходимые ткани для шитья. Приближается большой праздник, в связи с этим у нее уже много заказов на пошив платьев. Благодаря кредиту она сможет брать больше заказов и получить хорошую прибыль от деятельности.
texts.en: The name of this young, masterful woman is Saidamoh. She provides sewing services and has 10 years of experience in this field. Even though Saidamoh is 28 years old, she is not married and lives with her mother, father, brothers and sister-in-law. She was 18 years old when she started her sewing business and was able to retain regular customers since then. Saidamoh sews professionally, and her completed orders are very successful. Now Saidamoh wants to expand her business. She is planning to use the loan to buy a computerized sewing machine and necessary fabrics for sewing. A big holiday is approaching, and she already has many orders for sewing dresses. Thanks to this loan, she will be able to accept more orders and earn a good profit from her business.

loans.use: to buy a computerized sewing machine and necessary fabrics for sewing

loans.name: Fulgencia Mercedes

texts.es:
La Sra. Fulgencia Mercedes labora para un centro de salud publico elaborando todos los registros de medicinas y consultas medicas que se brindan en el centro de salud este trabajo lo realiza de lunes a viernes desde hace 27 años .
la Sra fulgencia Mercedes necesita este prestamo para la contruccion de un cuarto de habitacion ya que su familia va creciendo y necesita brindarle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Fulgencio Mercedes works in a public health center keeping the records of all the center's medicine and medical appointments.  She has worked this job Monday through Friday for 27 years.

Fulgencia Mercedes needs this loan to build a bedroom.  Her family's growing and she needs to give them a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy sand, cement, and rebar, and to pay for labor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a young cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a young cow

loans.name: Vijana Wazo Group

texts.en:
John, who is in his early 40's, is married with two kids. One of them is still in school and the other one is still small.  He has been running a genge business for one year now.  He works from 6 AM to 11 PM daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be John's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He will use this loan to rent a shop for selling from his genge business and to restock the out of stock items.  He dreams of progressing in his business.

John will share this loan with his loan group, Vijano Wazo, which consists of five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to rent a shop for selling from his genge business and to restock the out of stock items.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Hello, world! Meet Margaret, a mother of eight from Kitale, a remote town in the Rift Valley province of Kenya. She has spent the past 15 years of her life farming. She sells eggs, maize, milk, and vegetables produced on her farm. She also engages in personal business to make ends meet. Margaret is a go-getter and has a great desire to succeed in life. Of all the activities she involves herself in, poultry farming is closest to her heart. She enjoys waking up every morning to go and feed her animals. She is so close with her animals that she has nicknamed one of them “Koroti,” meaning no feathers on the head. 

Margaret wants to take full advantage of poultry farming as a profitable business venture. She would like to expand her poultry business, but the biggest challenge she faces is lack of capital. She is requesting a loan of KES 30,000, which she will use to buy additional poultry. With your loan, Margaret will be able to expand the poultry section on her farm. This will generate enough income to repay the loan, and she will also be able to save extra money. She is very concerned about her children’s education, so profits from farming will go to pay their school fees. Margaret dreams of a secure future for her children. She awaits your kindness.

Help out an enterprising mother with a creative mind and big dreams!

loans.use: To buy additional poultry to earn income for her children's school fees.

loans.name: Onesmus

texts.en:
Onesmus is 29 years old. He is married, and together with his spouse they have been blessed with 3 children of 4 years, 2 years and 1 month old. His spouse provides additional income for the family. He has a retail shop and he has been in this business for the last two years and it has been profitable.

Onesmus has requested a second loan with VisionFund Kenya of KES 30,000, which he will use to buy more stock of retail goods such as sugar, salt, cooking oil, rice, bread and milk. With the anticipated profits, he will be able to repay his loan as well as expand his business further.

His hope and dreams for the future is to grow his business from retail to wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more stock of retail goods such as sugar, cooking oil and milk for sell.

loans.name: Alcira Enoe

texts.es:
ALCIRA DE 49 AÑOS DE EDAD, SOLTERA CON DOS HIJOS MENORES DE EDAD,  ES ORIGINARIA DE LEÓN, LUGAR QUE ESTA UBICADO EN LA ZONA DE OCCIDENTE DEL PAÍS, ESTA MUJER SE CARACTERIZA POR SU FUERZA, TENACIDAD, GANAS DE SALIR ADELANTE CON SU FAMILIA.  ES DE CONDICIONES MUY POBRE PERO CON LA VOLUNTAD DE SACAR A DELANTE A SUS HIJOS Y BRINDARLE LA ESTABILIDAD QUE NECESITAN. LAMENTABLEMENTE ELLA NO PUDO ESTUDIAR POR FALTA DE RECURSOS ECONÓMICOS, POR LO TANTO QUIERE BRINDARLES A SUS HIJOS LA EDUCACIÓN QUE NECESITAN Y FORMARLOS EN PERSONAS DE BIEN.
GRACIAS A SU GANAS DE SALIR ADELANTE TIENE POR ACTIVIDAD ECONÓMICA  UNA PULPERIA EN SU CASA DE HABITACIÓN , ELLA LO DESEMPEÑA DESDE HACE VEINTE ANOS, ACTIVIDAD QUE CONSISTEN EN VENDER PRODUCTOS COMESTIBLES EN CANTIDADES PEQUEÑAS COMO: ARROZ, FRÉJOLES, AZÚCAR, LECHE, PAN, HUEVOS, FRUTAS, VERDURAS, HIELO, FÓSFOROS, JABÓN, DETERGENTE ETC. ELLA DEDICA UNAS DOCE HORAS DIARIAS A SU NEGOCIO PARA BRINDAR UN BUEN SERVICIO A SU CLIENTELA. EL OBJETIVO DEL CREDITO ES INVERTIR EN CAPITAL DE TRABAJO Y SURTIR SU NEGOCIO EN LA COMPRA Y VENTA DE PRODUCTOS COMESTIBLES PARA QUE EN UN FUTURO NO MUY LEJANO PUEDA OBTENER MEJORES INGRESOS.  ALCIRA AGRADECE LA  AYUDA QUE LOS INVERSIONISTAS KIVA LE BRINDAN A PERSONAS DE ESCASOS RECURSOS Y PAÍSES POBRE COMO ES NICARAGUA PARA TENER UN MEDIO DE TRABAJO DIGNO.
texts.en:
Alcira, age 49, a single woman with two children under age 18, is a native of León, which is located in the west of the country.  This woman is characterized by her strength, tenacity, and desires for her family to get ahead.  She comes from very poor conditions, but she has the will to provide for her children and offer them the stability they need.  Unfortunately, she couldn’t attend school due to lack of economic resources.  Therefore, she wants to offer her children the education they need and to train them to be good people.

Thanks to her desires to get ahead, she has a convenience store business in her house.  She has been performing this business for twenty years, and it consists of selling edible products in small quantities, such as rice, beans, sugar, milk, bread, eggs, fruit, vegetables, ice, matches, soap, detergent, etc.  She spends twelve hours each day working in her business to provide good service to her customers.  The purpose of the loan is to invest in working capital and supply her business by purchasing and selling edible products, so that in the near future she can have better income.  Alcira is grateful for the help that Kiva lenders offer to people of low resources and poor countries, like Nicaragua, so that they can have a decent means of work.

loans.use: to invest in her convenience store with products such as rice, beans, sugar, milk, bread, eggs, fruit, vegetables, ice, matches, soap, detergent, etc.

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is a jovial 55 year-old farmer based in Nkachie location in Central regions of Kenya. He is a faithful man who has stayed together with his wife Angelica for over 30 years. The couple is blessed with 4 children aged between 15 and 28. William has been doing farming nearly all his life. He owns a 1.5 acre land that he uses to grow vegetables and keep 4 goats and 5 heads of poultry. 

William is seeking a loan investment from Kiva lenders to purchase fertilizer. Like most other parents, December holidays and January tuition fees has emptied his pockets. To make matters worse, traders have set predatory pricing on farm inputs in anticipation of planting season. This situation calls for outside assistance to enable poor farmers like William to afford farm inputs to grow crops this year. 

Your loan will make it possible for William to purchase sufficient quantity of fertilizer that will help his crops grow healthy and green. Without fertilizer, a bumper harvest at the end of the season for William is simply unattainable.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Gilbert

texts.en:
Gilbert is a 35 year old, married man with 3 and 7 year old children. Both children attend school. He has been farming for 19 years and will use the loan from Kiva, to buy fertilizers to grow maize to sell at the local market. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his workers. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to grow maize and  to sell maize.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase water tank and pipes

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 31 years old, married and blessed with two school-going children aged nine and three years old. She has been in the tailoring business for the last 11 years and earns a monthly income of KES 30,000 which she uses to support her family.

She has applied for her first loan of KES 30,000 from VisionFund Kenya which she will use to buy more stock of sewing materials and threads for making table mats. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her children.

She desires to grow her business and be financially stable.

loans.use: To buy more sewing materials and thread for making table mats.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy vegetables, meat, grains etc. to prepare a variety of dishes for selling.

loans.name: Leoncie

texts.en:
Leoncie is 36 years old. She is married with 3 children aged between 11 months and 9 years; all of them go to school. She has been farming for 11 years. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy fertilizers to grow  maize and to sell maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay her workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to grow maize and sell the maize.

loans.name: Christophe

texts.en:
Christophe is a 36-year-old married man with kids aged 2 and 7. Both of them attend school. He has been farming for five years and will use the loan from Kiva to buy fertilizers to grow maize to sell at the local market. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for his maize crops

loans.name: Felicien

texts.en:
Felicien is a 34-year-old married man with one child who is five years old and attends school. Felicien has farmed for 12 years and will use the loan from Kiva to buy fertilizer to grow maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay for workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for his maize crops

loans.name: Ferdinand

texts.en:
Ferdinand is 35 years old. He is married. He is a farmer and has been farming for 19 years. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy fertilizers to grow maize to sell at the local market. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for his children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). loans.use: To buy fertilizers to grow maize and to sell at the local market

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 35 year old. He is married with 3 children aged between 4 and 14. All of them go to school. He has been farming for eight years and will use the loan from Kiva to buy fertilizers to grow maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for his maize plantation.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase construction materials to renovate the house.

loans.name: Theogene

texts.en:
Theogene is a 44 years old married man with 5 children aged between 6 and 23 years old. He has been farming for three years and will use the loan from Kiva to buy fertilizers to grow maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for his maize crops

loans.name: Msambeta Group

texts.en:
Lauryn is 32 years old and she sells second hand clothes to people in her community. She started this business in order to improve her family’s living standards by alleviating her household's level of poverty, and to pay school fees for her children. 

She will use the loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes, and this will help her to increase her profits. 

She plans of building a better house for her children, and dreams of sending them to better schools. The profits from her previous loans have been of great benefit to her, as she is now able to provide basic needs to her children.

loans.use: to buy second hand clothes

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is 27 years old and has two children aged four and two. None of them go to school. Patrick deals in poultry and tomato-growing, a business he started in 2000. He was given a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to buy tomato seeds and pesticides as well as feed for his poultry birds. 

He is greatly affected by poultry diseases, along with tomato diseases. He is doing his best to overcome the challenges.

loans.use: to buy tomato seeds and pesticides.

loans.name: Maria Del Rosario

texts.es: Maria es una señora de 36 años de edad y es madre soltera de sus 2 hijas de 13 y 15 años de edad, Maria vive arrendando junto a sus hijos que están estudiando, Maria es una señora colombiana que vino a Ecuador con el fin de tener una vida tranquila y conseguir trabajo y que si lo consiguió, ella va ainvertir el crédito en la compra de cuyes, la aspiración de Maria es quedarse en Ecuador y está muy contenta y agradecida  con las personas que hacen posible su crédito.
texts.en:
Maria is a 36-year-old woman and is a single mother of two children, ages 13 and 15. Maria rents together with her two children who are studying.

Maria is a Colombian woman who came to Ecuador in order to have a peaceful life and to find work, which she did. She is going to invest the loan in the purchase of guinea pigs. Maria’s aspiration is to stay in Ecuador. She is very happy and thankful to the people who are making her loan possible.

loans.use: to buy guinea pigs.

loans.name: Rabee

texts.en: Rabee is 27 years old from Baniswef. He is married to a housewife and has two sons. Five years ago, Rabee started a small electrical accessories project. Rabee wishes he could buy more kinds of electrical accessories to meet his customers' demands. Rabee can't afford this with his own funds as the income from his shop can barely cover his family's monthly expenses. Thus, Rabee requested a 5000 EPG loan to buy more electrical accessories to increase his sales and monthly income.

loans.use: To buy wires, cables, and lamps for his store to continue his sales.

loans.name: Juana Azurduy -23 Group

texts.es:
Elena es una mujer de 33 años de edad, soltera, tiene 2 hijos varones de 8 y 13 años y una hija mujer de 6 años, y su negocio es la venta de ropa.
Ella es de buena actitud, comprometida con su trabajo, generosa, amable, independiente, activa y responsable. Su negocio lo realiza en diferentes ferias de la ciudad como;  la feria ’16 de julio’ caracterizada por el comercio informal, donde se dice que se puede encontrar desde una aguja para coser hasta un tractor para arar. De clima frio y seco (2ºC -12ºC), a una altura promedio de 3800 metros sobre el nivel del mar.
Elena es de tez trigueña, cabello castaño, baja estatura, su lengua materna es el Aymará y habla español por cultura general (sentada al centro, usa chaqueta negra con una chalina en el cuello y lentes de aumento). Su vida la comparte con sus hijos que estudian en la escuela, viven en una casa alquilada que cuenta con agua potable, electricidad, alcantarillado y gas. Las ganas de generar mejores ingresos económicos para su familia la llevaron a liderar una banca de personas con negocios como; tejido a máquina, venta de vajillas, servicio técnico de equipos, venta de muebles, venta de edredones, confección de carteras de cuero, venta de salteñas, 
confección de polleras y servicio de transporte, para solicitar un préstamo y ampliar sus negocios. Su negocio es la venta de ropa de temporada, negocio que realiza de forma ambulante en diferentes ferias y comercios de la ciudad, exponiendo sus productos al aire libre en colgadores. También realiza su oferta en comercios a empleados de oficinas y personas que por sus labores no pueden salir de sus trabajos. “para conseguir clientes camino bastante, cargada de bolsos llenos de ropa, tengo clientes constantes y también me hacen pedidos…” comenta. Su sueño es tener una cadena de tiendas de ropa, ella desea realizar la compra de ropa por mayor para aprovechar la temporada y con los beneficios pagar el inicio escolar de sus hijos. Esta es la 2 secuencia de préstamo con la institución en 14 años que viene realizando esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Elena solicita un préstamo para la compra de ropa por mayor y con los beneficios pagar el inicio escolar de sus 3 hijos.
texts.en:
Elena, 33, is single and has 2 sons who are 8 and 13 and one daughter who is 6. She sells clothes.

She has a good attitude; she is committed to her work, generous, friendly, independent, active and responsible. She carries out her business at different festivals in the city such as 'the 16th July festival’ which is characterised by its informal trade, and where they say you can find everything from a needle to sew with to a tractor to plough with. The climate is cold and dry (2ºC -12ºC), at an average height of 3800 metres above sea level.

Elena has an olive complexion, brown hair, and a small stature. Her mother tongue is Aymara and she speaks general-knowledge Spanish (she is the one sitting in the centre wearing a black jacket, a scarf round her neck and glasses). She shares her life with her children who are at school. They live in a rented house which has drinking water, electricity, a sewage system and gas. The desire to earn more income for her family led her to head a bank for people with businesses to ask for a loan and expand these businesses, which include: machine textile making, crockery sales, technical equipment service, furniture sales, quilt sales, leather wallet making, pastry sales, making skirts and a transport service.

She has a travelling sales business which sells seasonal clothing, which she carries out at different festivals and trading spots in the city, exhibiting her products outdoors on coat-hangers. She also sells to office workers and to people whose jobs do not allow them to leave their workplaces. She comments: " to get customers I walk quite a lot, carrying bags full of clothing. I have regular customers and I also take orders…”. 

Her dream is to have a chain of clothing shops. She wants to buy clothes from a wholesaler to make the most of the season and use the profits to pay for her children to start school. This is the 2nd loan sequence with the institution in the 14 years that she has been running this business. This is why Elena is asking for a loan to buy clothing from a wholesaler and use the profits to pay for her 3 children to start school.

loans.use: to buy clothes from a wholesaler and use the profits to pay for her 3 children to start school

loans.name: Naguib

texts.en: Naguib is 38 years old from Baniswef. He is married to a housewife and has five sons. He works as a part time farmer so his income is dependent on the number of days he works. Two years ago, he started a fattening project by a 5000 EPG loan from TADE and he successfully repaid it on due date. Naguib is an ambitious young man so he decided to expand his small business by another 5000 EPG loan to buy a another head of cattle.

loans.use: To buy a head of cattle for fattening.

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud is 25 years old from Baniswef. He is married to a housewife and has a son and a daughter. He takes care of his aging, sick parents. He wishes he could start a fattening project to afford his family's basic and medical expenses. His wife will help him with his fattening project. Mahmoud requested a 7000 EPG loan from TADE to buy two head of cattle for fattening. He believes that this small project will be a great shift in his life.

loans.use: To buy two head of cattle for fattening

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a single 28 year-old-man from Baniswef. He works as a part time wedding chef. Ali has some cooking tools and supplies but they are very old and he wants to buy other modern tools and supplies to facilitate his job and quicken his performance. He believes that what really attracts customers are the supplies and the tools the chef uses. So he requested a 5000 EPG loan from TADE to buy more tools and supplies to attract his customers' attention and improve the quality of his cooking.

loans.use: To buy modern cooking tools and supplies such as a microwave oven, dishes, knives, pans, serving dishes, large bowls.

loans.name: Ronny

texts.es: Ronny is a married man and has two sons one is a male and he is 25 years old the other one is female and she is 18 years old (she is studying) The family live in La Paz and the house is registered as property of Ronny s children. Ronny is an upholsteres he fix any kind of furniture his father told him many years ago Ronny needs a loan to buy fabrics and tapestry to cover sofas this material are more expensive but it will be a good investment for Ronny and his ocupation Ronny s wife helps him with the family expenses but this time Ronny needs extra help and he apreciates his case is published in kiva
texts.en:
Ronny is a married man and has two children; one is a male and he is 25 years old, and the other one is a female and she is 18 years old (she is studying). The family lives in La Paz, and the house is registered as property of Ronny's children. Ronny is an upholsterer. He can fix any kind of furniture; his father taught him many years ago. 

Ronny needs a loan to buy fabrics and tapestry to cover sofas. These materials are more expensive, but it will be a good investment for Ronny and his occupation. 

Ronny's wife helps him with the family expenses, but this time Ronny needs extra help and he appreciates that his case is published on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy fabrics and tapestry to cover sofas

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 55 years old. He is married and together with his wife they have been blessed with seven children of ages between 23 and 30 years old. Richard is a dairy farmer, a business he has done for the last four years, earning a monthly income of KES 4,000.

Richard has requested his third loan with VisionFund Kenya of KES 16,000 which he intends to use in constructing a hay storage for his surplus cow food. With the anticipated profits, Richard will be able to support his family's well being. His hopes and dreams for the future are to start another business: poultry farming.

loans.use: to construct a hay storage

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
Laxmi is 35 years-old. She is married and has 2 children aged 9 and 6. In 2007, she established her poultry business. Working 7 days a week and 4 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid two loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy chicks for her business. In the future, Laxmi plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, raising poultry for eggs and meat is a very profitable business. Kiva loans are used to purchase chicks, food, and necessary medicine to keep the chickens healthy. Once matured, the chickens are sold at small butcher shops or in the many open air markets throughout the valley.

loans.use: to buy chicks for her business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 30 years married mother of three children. Her kids are 13, 7 and 3 years old. Malive does provide additional income for the family: she is a dairy farmer and has been in this business for 4 years now, earning a monthly income of KES 4,000. 

Besides dairy farming as her primary activity, she also sells fruits and vegetables and it has been profitable.

Mary has requested her first loan of KES 20,000 from VisionFund Kenya, which she intends to use to add stock of fresh vegetables like tomatoes, potatoes, carrots as well as leafy green vegetables. With the anticipated profits, Mary will be able to support her family. Her hopes and dreams for the future are to grow her business and be a wholesale supplier of vegetables as well as be financially stable.

loans.use: To buy fresh stock of vegetables

loans.name: Leidy

texts.es: Leidy is a young single mother of a 3 year old child she lives with her grandparents  in La Paz the house belongs to his grandfather Leidy sells clothes since 3 years ago she goes to many public offices and offer good payment plans to her customers Leidy wants a loan to acquire new stock from Peru and with a reasonable price for her in order to increase her incomes Leidy love her grandparents very much and she is the only person in the house that makes money so she will thank a lot the help from kiva but Leidy is healthy so she hopes you can trust her
texts.en: Leidy is a young single mother of a three-year-old child. She lives with her grandparents in La Paz. The house belongs to her grandfather. Leidy has sold clothes for three years. She goes to many public offices and offers good payment plans to her customers. Leidy wants a loan to acquire new stock from Peru and at a reasonable price for her in order to increase her income. Leidy loves her grandparents very much and she is the only person in the house that makes money so she will thank a lot the help from Kiva. Leidy is healthy so she hopes you can trust her.

loans.use: to acquire new stock (clothes)  from Peru.

loans.name: Gulhanym

texts.ru: Гульханым 45 лет, замужем, есть 2 детей. Гульханым, в качестве дополнительного дохода для своей семьи занимается животноводством и полеводством, начав свой бизнес 20 лет назад. Благодаря упорному труду Гульханым, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется 5 коров. Также на 1,12 Га земли, выращивает люцерну. Бизнес Гульханым в месяц приносит около 30,000 сом (KGS), из них 18,000 сом (KGS) от продажи экологически чистого, домашнего молока. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, она обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на увеличение поголовья дойных коров. Доходы от кредита Гульханым планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины.
texts.en:
Gulhanym is 45, married, and has two children.  She works as a crop and livestock farmer to earn some extra money for her family, and first started her business 20 years ago.  Thanks to her persistent efforts, she currently has five cows on her farm as well as 1.12 hectares of land for growing alfalfa.  Gulhanym's business brings in roughly 30,000 som per month, 18,000 of which comes from selling organic homestyle milk.  

To further develop her business, Gulhanym has requested a loan of 50,000 som from Bai Tushum Bank to increase her headcount of dairy cows.  She plans on using her extra income due to the loan to eventually add more livestock to her farm.

loans.use: buy dairy cows to increase her volume of organic milk sales

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy grains, sweet bread, candy, oil, etc., to offer her customers a variety of products.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a married woman and has been blessed with one child, who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

Beatrice operates a poultry-selling business, which has been operational for over four years. She mentioned disease outbreak causing losses as a challenge in the business. Beatrice dreams of becoming a wholesaler of poultry in the future. 

With the loan of 50,000 KES, she intends to purchase chicks and poultry feed. She joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and poultry feed

loans.name: Celmar

texts.en:
Celmar is a rice retailer from Iloilo, Philippines. He is 33 years old and has one child. Celmar has sold rice for more than 10 years now. This is the source of his income.

Celmar is asking for a loan to buy more rice. This loan will help him improve his stock, thus allowing him to sell more rice to his customers.

In the future, Celmar hopes of making his business a success. Moreover, he wants to save money for the future schooling of his child.

loans.use: to buy more rice

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase goats to raise and sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more incense and perfumes to sell them to her customers.

loans.name: Dora Zoila

texts.es:
EL Grupo de Crédito Simón Bolívar se reúne cada quince días en el sitio Cárcel Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía, que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.
En este lugar vive la señora Dora, tiene 21 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen dos hijos de  6 años y un bebé de 5 meses, la mayor estudian en escuela. Su esposo es artesano.
Doña Dora es una gran mujer que realiza el crédito  para ayudarle a su esposo para que pueda sacar adelante su negocio, él tiene una pequeña fábrica de ladrillos (material utilizado en la construcción de viviendas), en este lugar se encarga de elaborar y vender los ladrillos, el entrega sus productos a comerciantes que llegan hasta su fabrica para luego llevarlos a distintos lugares, lleva más de 10 años dedicado a esta actividad con la cual saca adelante a su familia honradamente.
Este crédito es para comprar leña, aserrín, agua y palmito que son los materiales que emplean para elaborar los ladrillos. Lleva 3 ciclos en el Grupo de Crédito y le gusta por la ayuda que le brindan los créditos. Sus sueños son darles lo mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The Simon Bolivar Credit Group meets every fifteen days in Carcel Canton Montecristi, known for its rich pre-colonial culture and for its handicrafts which are recognized nationally and wolrdwide. This is the area which makes the famous toquilla straw hats (Panama hats).

This is where Dora, who is 21 years old lives. She is married and has two children from that relationship, a six year old and a 5 month old baby. The eldest studies at school. Her husband is an artisan.

Dora is a great woman who is getting the loan in order to help her husband so that he will be able to move his business forward. He has a small brick factory (material used in the construction of houses) where he makes and sells bricks. He delivers his products to retailers that come to his factory and later take them to different areas. He has dedicated over ten years to this activity with which he raises his family honestly.

This loan is to buy wood, sawdust, water and palm fronds, which are the materials they use to make bricks. Dora has been with the credit group for three cycles and she likes it for the help that the loans provide. Her dreams are to give the best to her children.

loans.use: to buy wood, sawdust, water and palm fronds.

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley is 41 years old and from Lapogan, Gattaran, Cagayan. She is married with seven children. Her husband works as a construction worker while she sells rice and raise hogs. Despite the fact that both of them are earning, it is sometimes insufficient for all the needs of their seven children. 

That’s why Shirley wants to avail an education loan of PHP15,000 to pay for the tuition of one of her daughters. 

Her daughter Shermae is getting a BS in Information Technology. She hopes that one day she will be the one who will provide for her parents and family.

loans.use: to pay for her daughter's tuition fee

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma sends you her thanks for your generosity because her previous loan greatly enriched her business. She was able to buy spare parts for her computer units and pay for the maintenance of her shop. The loan also helped her provide for their daily needs and expenditures.

She is very positive that she could improve her business more if you will let her borrow again an amount of 50,000 PHP. This new loan will go to additional computer parts and maintenance costs of her business. Simultaneously, she could sustain the needs of her family through the help of this assistance.

Alma wants her business to prosper so that she can continue to provide for the educational needs of her children. She meets every week with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for parts and to cover maintenance costs of her computer shop

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny is 21 years old, married, and has one child in school.  

She is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Jenny requested a PHP 5,500 loan through NWTF in order to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Jenny has been raising pigs for two years now, and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, she would like to build and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Elsa works hard to support her family.

She has a buy and sell ginger tea business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening and food vending. Elsa is borrowing PHP 17,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients like ginger, sugar, plastic containers, etc for her buy and sell ginger tea business.

She successfully repaid her previous loan, and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Elsa has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like ginger, sugar, plastic containers, etc

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is 38 years old and has four children.  She is married, and all of her children are in school.

Lucia is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 9,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Lucia has been raising pigs for ten years now, and has borrowed five times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, she would like to build and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose works hard to support her family. Rose is married and has a business buying and selling vegetables and spices in the Philippines.

Rose requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock of vegetable and spices.

Rose has been in this business for 5 years now.

In the future, Rose would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of vegetable and spices

loans.name: Marcela

texts.en:
Marcela is 61 years old and married woman with two children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Marcela has a business selling peanuts in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 12,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more peanuts to sell.

Marcela has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, she would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more peanuts to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cereal grains, drinks, candy, cooking oil, detergents, etc. for stocking her store.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is thankful for the 8,000 PHP loan assistance granted to her as she was able to purchase quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 8,000 PHP loan for her to buy additional supplies of raw materials needed in making the rugs she sells. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her family’s daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Evelyn hopes for her business to grow bigger. She dreams of her family having a good life in the future. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for fabric, cloth, thread, needles, and other materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cement and wood to renovate his house.

loans.name: Ma. Pinky

texts.en:
